markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN DESCRIPTION FOR DOPPLER STATION 51197, EXCEPT THE MARK IS 30 FEET ABOVE GROUND RATHER THAN 50. AND THERE ARE NO LOCKED GATES IN REACHING THE STATION.  IT IS LOCATED ADJECENT TO THE SOUTHWEST CAPE LIGHTHOUSE. 4.2 KM (2.6 MI) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF FREDERIKSTED.  THE STATION IS A CROSS STAMPED IN A 15 CM STEEL PLATE WHICH IS BOLTED TO THE FLOOR OF A THEODOLITE TOWER WHICH IS PART OF SOUTHWEST CAPE LIGHT. THERE IS A STEEL INSTRUMENT STAND PERMANENTLY LOCATED OVER THIS MARK WHICH IS 1.280 METERS IN HEIGHT. THIS STRUCTURE ALSO HAS A ROOF AND LOVERED WINDOWS ON ONE AND A HALF SIDES. THERE IS ALSO A POLE THAT IS PLUMB TO THE MARK, ON TOP OF THE ROOF (GOOD FOR ELECTRONIC NAVIGATIONAL EQUIPMENT).  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.5 METERS ABOVE FLOOR OF PLATFORM.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1980. THE ROUTE TO THE STATION WAS BLOCKED BY LARGE PILES OF GRAVEL IN THE ROAD AND THE LAST 0.2 MILES WAS WALKED. THIS WOLL PROBABLY BE CLEARED AT ALATER DATE.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION IS LOCATED ON POINT OF LAND NEAR SHOYS MILL AND TOGETHER WITH STATION (BEE) REAR BEACON, FORM A PROLONGATION OF GREAT MIDDLE GROUND RANGE.  STRUCTURE IS USUAL TRIANGULAR DAYMARK ON CONCRETE POST.  STATIONS AEE AND BEE ARE NOT DESCRIBED IN BUOY LIST, 1925, U.S.L.H.S.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON TOP OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL KNOWN AS AJAK HILL.  THIS IS THE HIGHEST HILL IN THE RIDGE THAT FORMS THE BACKBONE OF THE NORTHEASTERN END OF ST. JOHN ISLAND.  IT IS N OF CAROLINA ESTATE AND S OF ANNABERG.  MOORS POINT ON E SIDE OF CORAL BAY AND TURNERS POINT ARE ON RANGE.  IT IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BOULDER 14 BY 11 BY 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER, IT BEARS 85 DEG 06 MIN W (TRUE) AND IS 11.92 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK, IT BEARS 11 DEG 51 MIN W (TRUE) AND IS 5.20 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CEG) STATION IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK, CEMENTED IN A LOW ROCK OUTCROP ON THE HIGHEST PART OF AJAK HILL, APPROXIMATELY 15 FT. N OF A WIRE FENCE RUNNING ALONG THE RIDGETOP, AND 6 FT. NW OF A 2-FT.-DIAMETER TREE.  TOP OF HILL IS VERY THICKLY WOODED WITH TREES, CACTUS, AND BRUSH UP TO 30 FT. IN HEIGHT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM CRUZ BAY, PROCEED E ON CENTER ROAD FOR ABOUT 5-1/2 MI. TO THE INTERSECTION WITH FREDERIKDAL ROAD ABOUT 1/2 MI. SW OF STATION.  FROM THIS INTERSECTION, ENTER THE BRUSH AND PROCEED NE ALONG THE WIRE FENCE WHICH LEADS GENERALLY ALONG THE RIDGETOP TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  THERE IS NO TRAIL AND THE HEAVY BRUSH NECESSITATES CLEARING A PATH.  THE WIRE FENCE PASSES 15 FT. FROM THE STATION ON THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRASS DISKS, CEMENTED IN ROCKS.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2008 (WEL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 0.4 MI (0.6 KM) EAST-NORTHEAST OF CRUZ BAY.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CRUZ BAY, GO NORTHWEST FOR ABOUT 70 M (229.7 FT) ALONG MAIN STREET, THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.2 MI (0.3 KM) ON A STREET TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 10.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 0.3 MI (0.5 KM) ON HIGHWAY 10 TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.   IT IS LOCATED 24.0 M (78.7 FT) NORTH FROM THE CENTERLINE OF HIGHWAY, 18.2 M (59.7 FT) NORTH-NORTHWEST FROM A UTILITY POLE, 16.6 M (54.5 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A UTILITY POLE, 6.2 M (20.3 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A 12-INCH (30 CM) TREE, 8.2 M (26.9 FT) SOUTH FROM THE CENTER OF A DRIVEWAY AND SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A 2 FT (0.6 M) BY 4 FT (1.2 M) ROCK OUTCROP PROJECTING 15 CM (6 INCHES) ABOVE THE GROUND.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON BOURDEAUS POINT.  THIS IS THE FIRST PROMINENT POINT TO THE WESTWARD OF STUMPY POINT, ON THE N SIDE OF ST. THOMAS, NEAR ITS W END.  THE POINT APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN FORMED BY VOLCANIC ACTION.  A ROCKY REEF EXTENDS FOR ABOUT 100 FEET OUT FROM THE POINT.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 30 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER.  THE FIRST POINT TO THE WESTWARD IS ON RANGE WITH THE N END OF SALT CAY.  IT IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK.  CRICKET ROCK LIES N 26 DEG W MAGNETIC AND A HOUSE IN BOURDEAUX BAY LIES S 80 DEG E MAGNETIC FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE EASTERN END OF THE HILL TOP THAT RISES ABOVE MARIA BLUFF POINT.  THIS POINT IS BETWEEN GREAT CRUZ BAY AND CHOCOLATE HOLE.  THE STATION LOOKS DOWN INTO CHOCOLATE HOLE TO THE E.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN AN OUTCROPPING BOULDER 1 METER W OF A GROUP OF LARGE BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A REGULAR BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE FLAT TOPPED ROCK LYING ON THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A REGULAR BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DEPRESSION OF BOULDER ON NE SIDE OF THE RIDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) THE STATION AND R.M.S 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1.5 MILES SOUTH OF CRUZ BAY, ST. JOHN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) RECOVERED EXACTLY AS DESCRIBED.  A BLACKTOP ROAD PASSES 175 FEET TO THE WEST.  A TWO RUT ROAD EXTENDS FROM THIS BLACKTOP ROAD UP TO WITHIN 10 FEET OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS IN EXCELLENT CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION, RM 1 AND RM 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCES TO THE REFERENCE MARKS CHECKED THE OLD DATA WITH THE EXCEPTION OF RM 2, WHERE A SHORTER DISTANCE OF 0.020 METERS WAS NOTED.  THE STATION MARK WAS USED AS THE ANTENNA SITE FOR GEOCEIVER STATION 51194.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1.1 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CRUZ BAY, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF MARIA BLUFF, WHICH LOOKS DOWN INTO CHOCOLATE HOLE ON THE EAST AND GREAT CRUZ BAY ON THE WEST.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CRUZ BAY, GO SOUTHWEST ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO AN INTERSECTION.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTHEAST ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE SOUTHEASTERLY ON THE MAIN PAVED, WINDING ROAD FOR 1.0 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWESTERLY ON GRAVELLED ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT FORK AND GO DOWNHILL ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FORK.  KEEP RIGHT FORK, UPHILL AND SOUTHWESTERLY, ON HARD-SURFACE ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO A REVERSE FORK.  TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO UPHILL ON HARD-SURFACE ROAD NORTHWESTERLY FOR 0.1 MILE TO A DIRT DRIVEWAY ON THE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.05 MILE ON DIRT DRIVE AND PATH TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK, NOT STAMPED, CEMENTED IN A DRILLHOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK THAT PROJECTS 1.4 FEET.  THE MARK IS LOCATED 244.4 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF A HOUSE, 79.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A STORAGE SHED, AND 3 FEET WEST OF A GROUP OF LARGE BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISC, NOT STAMPED, CEMENTED IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1.7 FEET, 0.6 FEET AT THE DISC.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISC, NOT STAMPED, CEMENTED IN A BOULDER THAT PROJECTS 1.5 FEET.  THE PROPERTY OWNER IS JOHN W. HOLTER, 32 EAST 4TH ST., BRIDGEPORT, PENNSYLVANIA.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 1.1 MILES SE OF CRUZ BAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 2007 (TAB) MARK NOT FOUND. MARK LIKELY DISTURBED BY RECENT HOUSING CONSTRUCTION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) SIGNAL IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHERNMOST POINT OF WATER ISLAND.  IT IS A BOLD, ROCKY POINT WHICH IS KNOWN AS BANANA POINT.  STATION IS ON A LARGE OVERHANGING ROCK OF A GRAYISH COPPER COLOR.  THE POINT IS THE SHORTEST DISTANCE FROM WATER ISLAND TO SIGNAL BELVEDERE.  COWELL POINT JUST SHOWS CLEAR FROM THIS STATION.  STATION IS ABOUT 6 FEET ABOVE THE HIGH WATER MARK AND ABOUT 5 FEET FROM THE HIGH WATER LINE.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRONZE DISK WEDGED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SLIGHT DEPRESSION IN THE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK CEMENTED IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK ON THE NEXT POINT TO THE WESTWARD.  FOR A WITNESS MARK A TRIANGLE WAS CUT IN A PINNACLE ROCK ON THE SHORE TO THE EASTWARD.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 12 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE AND WITNESS MARKS ALSO RECOVERED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS SIGNAL IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST HILL ON THE W SIDE OF MOSQUITO BAY.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN THE CENTER OF THE LARGEST ROCK ON THE HILL.  THE BOULDER PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND AND IS ABOUT 6 FEET LONG AND 4 FEET WIDE.  THE CENTER OF THE STATION IS IN RANGE WITH THE WESTERNMOST POINT ON THE MAINLAND AND THE NORTHERNMOST POINT OF SAVANA ISLAND.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS COVERED WITH GRASS.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 4 METERS E OF A BARB WIRE FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN CONCRETE IN A DEPRESSION IN A BOULDER.  WITNESS MARK IS A TRIANGLE CUT IN A ROCK.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 12.9 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1959)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1959 (HJB) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED AND WAS EVIDENTLY DESTROYED WHEN THE ROAD AND CONTROL TOWER WERE BUILT.  THE WITNESS MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED.  FOR PRESENT DAY RECOVERY THE DESCRIPTION SHOULD READ AS FOLLOWS--  LOCATED ABOUT 1000 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE HARRY S. TRUMAN AIRPORT TERMINAL BUILDING, ATOP THE HILL 43 FEET SSW OF THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE BUILDING SUPPORTING THE CONTROL TOWER AND AIRPORT BEACON, AND 16 FEET WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE ROAD.  A STANDARD DISK (UNSTAMPED) CEMENTED IN A DRILLHOLE IN THE CENTER OF A BOULDER 3 FEET IN DIAMETER AND 4 FEET ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (VES) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  THE BOULDER IS ABOUT 30 FT. SSW OF THE TRUMAN AIRPORT CONTROL TOWER.  THE CREST OF THE HILL AROUND THE STATION HAS BEEN CLEARED TO PROVIDE PARKING SPACE.  AS REPORTED IN 1958, THE BOULDER IN WHICH THE MARK IS LOCATED IS SOMEWHAT UNSTEADY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) THIS STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY O.W.S. IN 1918 WITH THE FOLLOWING NOTED EXCEPTIONS--TOP OF HILL IS NOW OCCUPIED BY CONTROL TOWER FOR HARRY S. TRUMAN AIRPORT AND ADMINISTRATION BUILDING FOR F.A.A.  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN BOULDER WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE GROUND AND IS ABOUT 4 FEET WIDE AND 6 FEET LONG.  BOULDER LOCATED 34 FEET SOUTH OF CONCRETE BUILDING AT BASE OF AIRPORT CONTROL TOWER.  WITNESS MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NOT RECOVERED.  TO REACH STATION, DRIVE WESTWARD ALONG VETERANS DRIVE FROM CENTER OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE TO AIRPORT DRIVEWAY, TURN LEFT AND FOLLOW DRIVE PAST AIRPORT HANGER, CONTINUE DRIVING UPHILL TO CONTROL TOWER. ROAD TO CONTROL TOWER IS POURED CONCRETE.  STATION IS LOCATED IN BOULDER ON WESTERN SIDE OF CONCRETE WALKWAY TO ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING AND CONTROL TOWER.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2.2 MILES WEST OF CENTER OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (EP) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN THE 1965 RECOVERY NOTE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2.6 MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS STATION IS ON THE S SHORE OF ST. THOMAS ISLAND, ABOUT 1/2 MILE NW OF DAVIDS POINT.  IT IS ON THE LARGEST OF A GROUP OF ROCKS JUST OFF SHORE.  FROM THE STATION, THE NEXT POINT TO THE NW IS JUST IN RANGE WITH THE OUTERMOST POINT OF SALT CAY.  THERE IS A REFERENCE MARK 27.2 METERS N 13 DEG E MAGNETIC FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2 MILES WEST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION BARE WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY O.W.S. IN 1918.  THIS STATION BELIEVED RECOVERED IN 1967 AND USED AS A HYDROGRAPHIC SIGNAL, AT THIS RECOVERY, SOME WHITEWASH REMAINS ON THE ROCK. REFERENCE MARK WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  TO REACH THIS STATION A SKIFF MUST BE USED, AS THE ROCK IS SEPARATED FROM SHORE BY A DISTANCE OF 10-15 METERS AND THE SHORE RISES STEEPLY FOR APPROXIMATELY 150 FEET BEHIND THE STATION.  RECOVERY SHOULD BE ATTEMPTED ONLY DURING PERIODS OF LITTLE OR NO SWELL AND FROM THE LEEWARD.  LANDING IS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT.  STATION IS 0.5 MILES NORTHWEST OF DAVID POINT.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5.5 MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE, ST. THOMAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE FIRST HILL SOUTH OF BARON BLUFF 1.2 MILES WEST OF THE MOUTH OF SALT RIVER BAY. ON THE PROPERTY OF E.COLON LINDSEY, 524 RIVEARA DRIVE, DAVIS ISLAND, TAMPA, FLA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF NORTH SHORE ROAD AND SCENIC ROAD GO NORTHERLY ON NORTH SHORE ROAD FOR 2.6 KM.(1.3 MI.) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT A MARINA ,KEEP LEFT AND GO WESTERLY ON NORTH SHORE ROAD FOR 2.2 KM.(1.35 MI.)TO A SHARP SIDE ROAD LEFT, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.4 KM.(0.25 MI.) UPHILL TO A GRAVEL ROAD RIGHT TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.4 KM.(0.25 MI.)TO WHERE ROAD TURNS AROUND ON TOP OF HILL AND THE STATION ON EAST SIDE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL  THE STATION IS A NOS BRASS DISK STAMPED---BARON BLUFF 1982---, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF AN IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE ONE INCH BELOW THE GROUND. IT IS LOCATED 8.2 METER (27.0 FT) EAST FROM THE EAST END OF THE CENTER LINE 2.1 METERS (7.0 FT) WEST FROM THE HIGH POINT ON THE EAST END OF HILL  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.6 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US NAVY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK, A U.S. NAVY OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE TRIANGULATION DISK, HAD BEEN PRIED OFF WITH THE SHANK REMAINING INTACT.  A STANDARD DISK WAS SET IN THE SAME POSITION AT THIS TIME.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STATION MARK WAS USED AS THE ANTENNA SITE FOR GEOCEIVER STATION 51198.  A DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8.5 MILES EAST OF CHRISTIANSTED, ON THE EASTERNMOST POINT OF ST. CROIX.  IT IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BY THE MUNICIPALITY OF CHRISTIANSTED.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE EAST END FIRE STATION, WHICH IS ABOUT 4 MILES EAST OF CHRISTIANSTED, GO EAST ON A PAVED WINDING ROAD FOR 1.8 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD AND SIGN ST. CROIX YACHT CLUB ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE EAST FOR 0.55 MILE TO A FORK, TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO EAST ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO END OF PAVEMENT, CONTINUE EAST ON GRAVELLED ROAD FOR 1.35 MILE TO THE END OF ROAD AND THE STATION IN THE CENTER OF THE ROAD LOOP.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED BART USNO 1975 1977, SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 63 FEET WEST OF THE CENTER OF A GRAVELLED ROAD, 59 FEET NORTH OF A GRAVELLED ROAD AND 9.5 FEET NORTHWEST OF A STEEL RANGEPOLE THAT IS CEMENTED IN A LARGE STEEL BARREL PROJECTING 2 FEET.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A U.S. NAVY OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE REFERENCE DISK, STAMPED BART RM 1 1975, SET IN THE TOP OF A 12-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 34.5 FEET NORTHEAST OF A RANGEPOLE, 33.5 FEET WEST OF THE EASTERN BREAK OF THE POINT AND 33 FEET WEST OF THE CENTER OF A GRAVELLED ROAD.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A U.S. NAVY OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE REFERENCE DISK, STAMPED BART RM 2 1975, SET IN TOP OF A 18-INCH ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH.  IT IS 36.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A RANGEPOLE, 35 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTHERN BREAK OF THE POINT AND 23 FEET NORTH OF THE CENTER OF A GRAVELLED ROAD.  AZIMUTH MARK IS U.S. NAVY OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE TRIANGULATION STATION TAM.  MARK IS A 1/2-INCH DIAMETER BRASS BOLT CEMENTED IN MASS OF CONCRETE SURROUNDED BY ROCKS.  THE BOLT PROJECTS 3 INCHES WITH CHISELED CROSS ON TOP.  IT IS ON THE EAST EDGE OF SUGARLOAF HILL WHICH IS THE HIGHEST HILL WEST OF THE STATION.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH FROM THE STATION, GO WEST ON GRAVELLED ROAD FOR 1.35 MILE TO THE START OF PAVED ROAD AND A SIDE ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT, SOUTHERLY, AND UPHILL ON TRACK ROAD TO TOP OF SUGARLOAF HILL AND THE MARK ON THE EASTERNMOST EDGE OF THE HILL. A 4-WHEELDRIVE OR 30 MINUTE PACK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 8.5 MILES EAST OF CHRISTIANSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED. THE DISK IS NO LONGER THERE BUT THE STEM IS SECURED IN THE CONCRETE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE EASTERN END OF THE BLUFF THAT EXTENDS OUT FROM BATTERY POINT BETWEEN CORAL HARBOR AND HURRICANE HOLE.  THE RUINS OF AN OLD BATTERY LIE ABOUT 50 FEET BACK OF THE STATION.  TO THE E AND W OF THE STATION EXTEND TWO GRAVEL BEACH BAYS.  HERMITAGE HOUSE SHOWS JUST ABOVE RED POINT TO THE E OF THE STATION.  STATION IS MARKED BY A U.S.G. AND G.S. BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A CREVICE OF THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHWEST END OF ST CROIX ON THE SECOND POINT NORTH OF HAMS BAY.  STATION IS UNDER AN OBSERVATION PLATFORM SUPPORTED BY 4 CONCRETE COLUMNS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FREDERIKSTED PIER, GO EAST FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSS STREET, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 6.7 KM (4.2 MI) TO A FORK, SCENIC ROAD, KEEP LEFT AND CONTINUE NORTH FOR 0.5 KM (0.3MI) TO A SIDEROAD LEFT KEEP RIGHT ON MAIN ROAD FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A FORK, TAKE FORK TO LEFT AND GO 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO BEACH AND STATION TO THE SOUTH OF THE END OF ROAD.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD USN DISK STAMPED---BAY 1975---, CEMENTED INTO THE ROCK BENETH A OBSERVATION PLATFORM. IT IS LOCATED 16 METERS (52.5 FT) SOUTH FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF ROCKY SHORELINE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 4 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2007 (HSI) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION IS LOCATED ON POINT OF LAND NEAR SHOYS MILL AND TOGETHER WITH (AEE) FRONT BEACON FROM PROLONGATION OF GREAT MIDDLE GROUND RANGE.  STATION IS NOT DESCRIBED IN BUOY LIST, 1925, U.S.L.H.S.  IT IS 425 YARDS E OF FRONT BEACON, AND IS THE USUAL DAYMARK MOUNTED ON A CONCRETE POST.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION ON THE HILL SHOWN ON BRITISH ADMIRALTY CHART 485, AS 620 FT HIGH.  THIS HILL FORMS PART OF THE BACKBONE OF THE E END OF ST. CROIX.  IT IS 3/4 MILE SE OF COTTON VALLEY RUINS.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK IN TOP OF A 6-INCH DIAMETER, 24 INCHES LONG, CEMENT POST PROJECTING ABOUT 6 INCHES.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS SAME AS SURFACE MARK ONLY SHORTER.  TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE PUT IN BUT NO DISTANCES OR DIRECTIONS TO THEM WERE MEASURED, AS THIS WAS LEFT UNTIL THE STATION SHOULD BE OCCUPIED.  AN 8-FOOT HIGH SCAFFOLD WAS BUILT OVER THE STATION.  BEST APPROACHED BY A TRAIL LEADING UP THE VALLEY FROM COTTON VALLEY RUINS TO THE TOP OF THE RIDGE AND THENCE EASTWARD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) FOUND AS DESCRIBED, EXCEPT THAT THE REFERENCE MARKS HAD BEEN REMOVED.  THERE WAS NO TIME TO RETURN TO THIS STATION AND REPLACE THEM.  STATION WAS OCCUPIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) HILLTOP IS USED AS OFF-SHORE SIGNAL.  NO SEARCH FOR MARK.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF OCTAGONAL STRUCTURE (SO CALLED) ON THE SUMMIT OF THE LITTLE HILL BACK OF THE RESIDENCE OF MR. BRONDSTED (VILLA OLGA), AT THE W END OF ST. THOMAS HARBOR.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS STATION IS NEAR THE SW CORNER OF CAREEN OR MANECKE HILL.  THE CENTER OF THE STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION BRASS DISK PLACED IN THE CENTER OF A CIRCULAR POST OF CONCRETE 4 FEET IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTING ABOUT 10 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  THIS CONCRETE BASE WAS AT ONE TIME THE BOTTOM OF A WATER TANK.  THE BASE OF THE OCTAGONAL STRUCTURE REFERRED TO IN THE OLD DESCRIPTION OF BELVEDERE IS STILL PRESENT, THE STRUCTURE ITSELF HAVING BEEN BLOWN AWAY BY THE RECENT HURRICANE.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS FENCED IN BY A STONE FENCE 1 FOOT HIGH.  THE TOP OF THE HILL HAS AN OCTAGONAL CONCRETE FLOORING.  IN THE CENTER OF THIS FLOORING THERE IS THE CONCRETE BASE.  THERE IS A CONCRETE STEP ON THE S SIDE AND THE N SIDE.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH GRASS.  NO TREES EXIST.  ON THE NE END OF THE TOP OF THE HILL THERE IS ANOTHER CIRCULAR BASE OF CONCRETE 4 FEET IN DIAMETER.  THERE IS A LARGE HOLE IN THE CONCRETE WHERE ONCE A FLAGSTAFF RESTED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A CROSS ON AN OCTAGONAL BASE AND BEARS N 59 DEG E.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET ON THE CONCRETE BASE OF THE FLAGSTAFF AND BEARS N 40 DEG E.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3 IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK SET IN A HIGH CONCRETE CHIMNEY ON WATER ISLAND AND BEARS S 82 DEG E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (JH) THE STATION APPEARS TO BE INTACT.  IT IS MARKED BY A STANDARD DISK WHICH DOES NOT APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN DISTURBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS NEAR THE SOUTH CENTRAL PART OF THE ISLAND ALONG THE SHORE OF AND AT THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE CITY OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE IN THE VICINITY OF HAVENSIGHT POINT ON THE WEST INDIAN COMPANY DOCKS (CRUISE SHIPS) AT THE WESTERN END OF A PIER WHICH EXTENDS INTO ST THOMAS HARBOR FROM HAVENSIGHT POINT.  REACH STATION FROM CHARLOTTE AMALIE BY TRAVELLING EAST ON VETERANS DRIVE (HIGHWAY 30) TO THE HAVENSIGHT MALL AT THE EAST EDGE OF TOWN, TURN RIGHT INTO THE HAVENSIGHT MALL COMPLEX AND HEAD SOUTH AND WEST TO THE HEAD OF THE PIER THENCE CONTINUE SOUTHWEST ON THE PIER TO THE END AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT NEAR THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE PIER.  THE STATION MARK IS AN NOS BRONZE DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE SURFACE OF THE PIER, IT IS, 75.94 FT (23.15 M) NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF THE PIER, 9.35 FT (2.85 M) EAST OF THE WESTERNMOST EDGE OF THE PIER, 6.47 FT (1.97 M) EAST OF A 10 CM DIAMETER STEEL NAVIGATIONAL LIGHT STANDARD, 4.75 FT (1.45 M) SOUTHEAST OF THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF THE PIER AND 3.85 FT (1.17 M) WEST OF THE WEST LEG OF A GUARD RAIL STANCHION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2006)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2006 (DSR) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 (WEL) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED NO PUBLIC ACCESS.  THE DOCK IS FENCED OFF. ACCESS MUST BE OBTAINED FROM DOCK SECURITY.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN A MASSIVE RETAINING WALL
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (PDC) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION SITUATED ABOUT 40 METERS W OF AND 12 FEET BELOW THE HIGHEST PART OF BUCK ISLAND.  ABOUT 35 METERS E OF THE STATION THERE IS A LARGE CONSPICUOUS TAMARIND TREE.  UNDERNEATH THE TREE ARE THE RUINS OF A HOUSE.  STATION MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE OUTCROPPING ROCK.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED.  NO OBSERVATIONS WERE TAKEN AT OR ON THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  THE TAMARIND TREE REFERRED TO WAS MADE A REFERENCE MARK.  FROM MARK TO NEAREST (W) SIDE TRUNK IS 43.37 METERS.  FROM GREEN TO THIS TREE, CALLED TREE ON TOPOGRAPHIC SHEET K AND LISTED, THE ANGLE IS 206 DEG 35 MIN.  STATION OCCUPIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. THE TAMARIND TREE MENTIONED IN THE PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION IS A GOOD REFERENCE POINT.  THERE IS A BOAT DOCK ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE  ISLAND. FROM THE DOCK PACK EAST ALONG SHORELINE FOR 100 METERS TO A SMALL PAVILLION, PICNIC AREA AND TRAIL. PACK NORTHERLY UPHILL ON MAIN TRAIL TO TOP OF RIDGE THENCE EASTERLY ALONG RIDGE TO STATION ON SOUTH SIDE OF TRAIL, JUST BEFORE REACHING A LIGHT TOWER.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.8 METERS

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS IN THE TOP CENTER OF BLACKBEARDS CASTLE ELEVATION OF WHICH AS DETERMINED BY TOPOGRAPHY IS 252 FEET.  BLACKBEARDS CASTLE IS SOMETIMES KNOWN AS KIAERS TOWER AND IS LOCATED ON GOVERNMENT HILL.  PRACTICALLY THE CENTER OF THE TOWN OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION USED AS SIGNAL AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) TOWER STILL IN PLACE.  A LARGE ROUND STONE TOWER ON A HILL EAST OF GOVERNORS HOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--AT CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION BLACK IS A STANDARD BRASS DISC SET IN A LARGE BOULDER ON THE SOUTHERNMOST EDGE OF BLACK POINT.  APPROXIMATELY 3 METERS FROM EDGE OF BLUFF.  THIS IS ALSO HIGHEST PORTION OF BLACK POINT.  BLACK POINT IS 1.1 MILES WEST OF HARRY S. TRUMAN AIRPORT.  TO REACH THIS STATION A SKIFF IS ADVISABLE SINCE MUCH DENSE UNDERGROWTH COVERS THE POINT.  LANDING SHOULD BE MADE ON WESTERN SIDE OF BLACK POINT ON ROCKS INSIDE THE COVE CREATED BY BLACK POINT.  FROM LANDING, WALK TO S. END OF BLACK POINT AND HIGHEST POINT ON SOUTH END.  MARK RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  NO REFERENCE MARKS FOUND, NONE DESCRIBED IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--3.2 MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL PART OF THE ISLAND IN THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE CITY OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE ON GOVERNMENT HILL ON A STONE TOWER KNOWN AS BLACKBEARD CASTLE.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE CENTER OF THE FLAGPOLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2005 (KEN) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE ROCKY LEDGE FORMING THE EASTERN POINT OF THATCH CAY.  IT IS ABOUT 50 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER.  MARKED BY A STANDARD U.S.C. AND G.S. BRASS TRIANGULATION MARK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN A CRACK OF A FLAT-TOPPED LEDGE.  THE MARK IS 6 METERS FROM THE RISING IMPASSABLE CLIFF TO THE WESTWARD.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A CRACK OF THE ROCK ABOUT 0.6 METER FROM THE BASE OF THE CLIFF.  IT IS 5.88 METERS DISTANT, AND BEARS S 80 DEG W (PRISMATIC COMPASS), FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION AND RM NO.1 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS THE FLAGSTAFF ON THE WESTERN MIDDLE OF BLUEBEARDS CASTLE LOCATED ON THE FIRST HILL, EASTERN EXTREMITY OF THE TOWN.  THIS HILL IS GENERALLY KNOWN AS FREDERICKSBERG.  THE ELEVATION OF THE TOP OF THE TOWER AS DETERMINED BY TOPOGRAPHY IS 258 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  PREVIOUS DESCRIPTION ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--AT CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY O.W.S. IN 1918.  DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2005 (KEN) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL PART OF THE ISLAND IN THE EASTERN PART OF THE CITY OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE ATOP BLUEBEARD HILL AND ON THE STONE TOWER KNOWN AS BLUEBEARD CASTLE.  THE OBJECT IS A FLAGPOLE PROJECTING ABOVE THE STONE TOWER AND IT DOES NOT APPEAR TO COINCIDE WITH THE CENTER OF THE TOWER.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE CENTER OF THE FLAGPOLE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION IS ON THE W SHORE OF MAINLAND AND ABOUT 10 METERS FROM EDGE OF BLUFF ABOUT 30 FEET HIGH.  THE MARK OVERLOOKS THE SOUTHERN SHORE.  THE STATION IS ON THE E SHORE OF NARROW PASSAGE INTO BOTANY BAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED ON PAGE 1 PAMPHLET 624.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--6 MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON HIGHEST PART OF NORTHERLY PEAK OF BODKIN HILL, NW END OF ST. CROIX.  THE HILL IS COVERED WITH GRASS.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK IN THE TOP OF A 6-INCH DIAMETER CEMENT POST, 18 INCHES LONG.  TOP OF POST PROJECTS 3 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, A CEMENT POST, 6 INCHES DIAMETER, 18 INCHES LONG, HAVING A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK IN ITS TOP, SET ON THE SOUTHWESTERN BREAK OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SIMILAR MARK ON THE NW BREAK OF THE HILL.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - TOP OF POLE - 3.90 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION MARK HAD BEEN BROKEN OFF AT GROUND LEVEL.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT FOUND AND BELIEVED DESTROYED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 4.3 MI. NORTHEAST OF FREDERIKSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2007 (HI) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT CAN BE DRIVEN TO FROM SCENIC ROAD APPROACHING FROM THE WEST.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON APPROXIMATELY THE HIGHEST PART OF BOOBY ROCK ON S SHORE OF ST. JOHN ISLAND, AND JUST W OF RAMS HEAD.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A DEPRESSION OF THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1924)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION LIES BETWEEN THE TWO HIGHEST PEAKS ON BOOBY ROCK IN A DEPRESSION ABOUT FOUR FEET LOWER THAN THE PEAKS.  BOOBY ROCK IS OFF THE SOUTH SHORE OF ST. JOHN AND APPROXIMATELY 1/2 MILE WEST OF RAM HEAD.  MARKED BY AN UNSTAMPED HYDROGRAPHIC DISK CEMENTED IN THE ROCK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5 MILES EAST OF CRUZ BAY, ST. JOHN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) THIS STATION WAS ORIGINALLY ONLY A FLAG CUT IN BY TRIANGULATION.  LATER THE STATION WAS MARKED BY A SPOT OF CEMENT IN THE CRACK OF, AND ON ONE OF A GROUP OF BOULDERS LYING ON THE SW PART OF THE TOP OF THE GRASS COVERED HILL.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE NE RIDGE OF BOURDEAUX MOUNTAIN.  STATION OVERLOOKS CAROLINA ESTATE AND CORAL BAY.  THE HILL SLOPES ABRUPTLY FROM THE STATION ON THE E SIDE AND MORE GENTLY ON THE N SIDE.  THE HIGHEST TIP OF THE HILL IS 200 METERS TO THE S.  N SIDE OF USHERS CAY, HERMITAGE HOUSE, MT. PLEASANT, OUTER TIP OF LAGOON POINT AND W TANGENT OF NORMAN ISLAND ARE ON RANGE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A HOLE IN A 0.4 METER DIAMETER FLAT-TOPPED ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A SMALL MASS OF CEMENT ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL ROCK ON THE EASTERN BREAK OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 BEARS N 55 DEG 43 MIN E AND IS 6.020 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 BEARS S 32 DEG 05 MIN E AND IS 9.480 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1928)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1928 THE REFERENCE MARKS ARE AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION MARK IS AS FOLLOWS--  A FLAT-TOPPED ROCK HAVING A DRILL HOLE APPROXIMATELY 1-3/4 INCHES DEEP, IN WHICH HAS BEEN SET A COPPER BOLT SIMILAR TO THE ONE MARKING STATION MINNAHILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1957)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1957 STATION MARK WAS NOT FOUND BUT MAY STILL EXIST AS THERE IS A LOT OF LOOSE ROCK IN THE VICINITY OF THE STATION WHICH MAY BE PILED ON TOP OF IT.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) THIS WAS AN ARBITRARY NAME GIVEN TO THE OLD STONE MILL SITUATED NEAR THE S SHORE LINE ABOUT 1/2 MILE SW OF BETTYS HOPE CHIMNEY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION TRIANGULATION DISK IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CLIFF ON THE SW POINT OF CABRITE POINT.  IT IS LOCATED ON TOP OF THE NECK THAT FORMS THE CLIFF KNOB HERE.  A DEEP WEATHER BEATEN GULLY IS JUST TO THE SE.  ELEVATION BY TOPOGRAPHY - 86 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  MARKED BY AN UNSTAMPED HYDROGRAPHIC DISK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4.5 MILES EAST OF CRUZ BAY, ST. JOHN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  MARKED BY AN UNSTAMPED HYDROGRAPHIC DISK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4.5 MILES EAST OF CRUZ BAY, ST. JOHN.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 UNITED STATES VIRGIN ISLANDS, ISLAND AND COUNTY OF SAINT THOMAS, SOUTH CENTRAL SAINT THOMAS IN THE PORT CITY OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.   STARTING FROM THE UNITED STATES COAST GUARD STATION IN CHARLOTTE AMALIE, AT THE INTERSECTION OF PORT PLADSON AND HIGHWAY 30, GO 0.52 MI (0.8 KM) WESTERLY ALONG HIGHWAY 30 TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT ACROSS THE ROAD FROM A BASEBALL PARK, SET ATOP A CONCRETE SEAWALL   0.4 M (1.3 FT) NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE, 28.1 M (92.2 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A TRAFFIC LIGHT POLE, 17.6 M (57.7 FT) SOUTH OF THE HIGHWAY CENTERLINE, 9.6 M (31.5 FT) EAST OF AN IRON FENCE.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN A MASSIVE RETAINING WALL
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE ISLAND ABOUT 1.5 MI (2.4 KM) SOUTHWEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE ATOP GRAMBOKOLA HILL. REACHED FROM CHARLOTTE AMALIE GO WEST ON THE MORAVIAN HIGHWAY TO THE AIRPORT ACCESS ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT ON THE AIRPORT ACCESS ROAD AND PROCEED SOUTHWEST FOR 0.15 MI (0.24 KM) TO A FORK ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH BEARING RIGHT AT ALL FORKS FOR 0.6 MI (1.0 KM) TO A GATE.  PASSAGE THROUGH THE GATE MAY BE COORDINATED THROUGH THE FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINITRATION AT THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ST THOMAS AIRPORT.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND PROCEED UP THE HILL FOR 0.2 MI (0.3 KM) TO THE SECOND ROAD ON THE LEFT, TURN LEFT AND PROCEED UPHILL FOR 0.15 MI (0.24 KM) TO THE POINT WHERE THE PAVEMENT ENDS, THENCE BEAR RIGHT ON A DIM TRACK ROAD UP THE HILL FOR 0.15 MI (0.24 KM) TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION. THE STATION MARK IS AN UNSTAMPED COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY BRONZE DISK WHICH IS SET IN A MASS OF CONCRETE ATOP A PARTIALLY EXPOSED BOULDER. THE DISK IS CANTED AT AN ANGLE AND IS NOT LEVEL.  THERE IS WRITING IN THE CONCRETE OF THE MONUMENT STATING THAT THE MARK WAS RESET ON 12-21-89 BY AM.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL NORTH OF AN ELEVATED SQUARE CONCRETE CISTERN.  THERE IS AN UNSTAMPED REFERENCE MARK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK OUTCROPPING 4.5 METERS (14.8 FT) NORTHEAST OF THE STATION.  THE MARK IS 5.165 METERS (16.946 FT) ENE OF THE AIRPORT BEACON.
markers.setting: undefinedOBJECT SURROUNDED BY MASS OF CONCRETE
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION IS THE TOP OF BUCK ISLAND LIGHT HOUSE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1942)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1942 (OWS) ACCORDING TO RECOLLECTIONS, THIS STATION IS NOT THE CENTER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE BUT IS ABOUT 3 METERS INSHORE OF THE CENTER OF THE LIGHT.  IT IS MARKED AND REFERENCED BY STANDARD DISKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CFG) DESCRIPTIONS REPORT STATION AS BEING THE CENTER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ON BUCK ISLAND.  AN ECCENTRIC STATION WAS LOCATED VERY NEAR THE LIGHTHOUSE.  IT IS AN IRON PIN IN LOW ROCK APPROXIMATELY 7 FEET N OF THE N SIDE OF LIGHTHOUSE AND BEARS N. 25 DEG W. FROM LIGHTHOUSE.  FROM THE ECCENTRIC STATION, ALL OF ST. THOMAS CAN BE SIGHTED BUT THE LIGHTHOUSE BLOCKS SIGHT ON LITTLE ST. JAMES AND THE S PART OF ST. JOHN ISLAND.  ONE REFERENCE MARK WAS LOCATED. IT IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK SET IN A 5- BY 8- BY 4-FOOT HIGH BOULDER.  BEARING AND DISTANCE FROM LIGHTHOUSE IS S. 82 DEG W. AND 35 FEET FROM CENTER.  ACCESS--A SEAWORTHY BOAT WILL BE NECESSARY TO REACH BUCK, SINCE OPEN SEA IS ENCOUNTERED.  CONSULT MAP OF ST. THOMAS AND LOCATE BUCK ISLAND TO THE SE OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTIONS REPORT THE STATION AS BEING THE CENTER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ON BUCK ISLAND.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4.5 MILES SSE OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  LANDING MAY BE MADE ON THE WESTERN END OF BUCK ISLAND AT PIER IN COVE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4.3 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS PRESUMED TO BE THE CENTER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE ON BUCK ISLAND JUST SOUTHEAST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE IN ST THOMAS ISLAND.  IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT THE HISTORICAL DESCRIPTIONS AND RECOVERY NOTES OF THIS STATION CONTRADICT EACH OTHER AS TO THE NATURE OF THE STATION. THE OBJECT OBSERVED AT THIS TIME WAS THE PHYSICAL CENTER OF THE LIGHTHOUSE AND IT CHECKED IN AZIMUTH ORIENTATION WITHIN THIRD ORDER LIMITS BUT INSUFFICIENT OBSERVATIONS WERE OBTAINED TO COMPUTE A CHECK POSITION.  THIS LIGHTHOUSE IS LISTED AS LIGHT NUMBER 27385 (BUCK ISLAND LIGHT) IN THE 1993 EDITION OF THE U.S.C.G. LIGHT LIST VOLUME III.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE TOP CENTER OF BUCK ISLAND.  THE STATION CAN BE REACHED BY BOAT, GOING TO A DOCK ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF BUCK ISLAND THEN PACKING EAST ALONG SHORELINE TO A PICNIC AREA AND TRAIL UP MOUNTAIN.  FOLLOW TRAIL TO TOP OF RIDGE THEN FOLLOW TRAIL EAST ALONG RIDGE TO STATION.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF A WHITE LIGHT ATOP A 10 METER STEEL TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS STATION IS ON THE OUTER TIP OF BULIVUN POINT.  IT IS ABOUT FIFTEEN FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER.  A LEDGE OF THE POINT 5 METERS TO THE SOUTHWESTWARD IS SLIGHTLY HIGHER.  THE STATION SEES THE OUTER PART OF BOTH DITLESS POINT AND MARIA BLUFF.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A DEPRESSION OF THE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A REGULAR BRASS DISK CEMENTED INTO A SHALLOW DRILL HOLE IN A DEPRESSION OF THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1924)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS WHITEWASHED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE WESTERN HIGH WALL OF THE RUINS CALLED BULOWS MINDE 1-1/2 MILES W OF CHRISTIANSTED.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO THE TOP OF THE WALL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE BOTTOM FRONT STEP TO THE HOUSE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SIMILAR DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CENTER OF THE SANDSTONE CORNER STONE OF THE E SIDE OF THE FOUNDATION OF THE OLD SUNDIAL STANDING ON THE W SIDE OF THE RUINS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A SIMILAR DISK IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE BRICK HORSE-TROUGH ON THE S SIDE OF THE CEMENT CATCH WATER ON THE W SIDE OF A LARGE CISTERN.  REFERENCE MARK NO.4 IS A SIMILAR DISK CEMENTED IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF A BRICK PIER 3 FEET HIGH AND 1-1/2 FEET SQUARE ON THE N SIDE OF RUINS, WHICH STANDS AT THE END OF SHORT RETAINING WALL ON THE N SIDE OF THE RUINS.  TOP OF POLE - 3.0 METERS ABOVE STATION MARK, OR 8.0 METERS ABOVE THE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1919.  REFERENCE MARKS 3 AND 4 HAVE BEEN DESTROYED DUE TO RENOVATION OF THE HOUSE.  THE HOUSE IS NOW THE RESIDENCE OF MR. ROBERT ARMSTRONG, WHO SHOULD BE CONTACTED AT THE BUCCANEER HOTEL CNCERNING ACCESS TO THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BEESTON HILL WESYLYN HOLINESS CHURCH OFF OF CENTERLINE ROAD, GO NORTHWESTERLY ON PAVED ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT ONTO DIRT, THEN PAVED, SIDE ROAD, AND CONTINUE FOR 0.3 MILE TO A WROUGHT IRON GATE.  CONTINUE THROUGH GATE FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE ARMSTRONG RESIDENCE AND STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 1.6 MI. WEST OF CHRISTIANSTED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE WEST END OF ST CROIX, SOUTH OF BUTLER BAY ON THE ROCKY SHORELINE OPPOSITE ROAD LEADING TO BUTLER BAY RUINS.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM FREDERIKSTED PIER GO ONE BLOCK EAST TO A CROSS STREET, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON MAIN ROAD FOR 4.2 KM (2.6 MI) TO STATION ON LEFT AND THE OLD STONE ENTRANCE TO BUTLER BAY RUINS ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED---BUTLER BAY 1980---, CEMENTED INTO THE ROCKY SHORELINE IN A MASS OF CONCRETE. IT IS LOCATED 22.9 METERS (75.1 FT) NORTHWEST FROM THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF AN OLD STONE STRUCTURE, 13.4 METERS (44 FT) WEST FROM A PK NAIL IN LARGE LONE TREE AND 1.8 METERS (6 FT) EAST FROM WATERS EDGE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THE STATION IS SITUATED ON THE INNERMOST OF THE FLAT-TOPPED ROCKS OFF CABRITE POINT.  THIS ROCK IS SEPARATED FROM THE MAIN POINT BY A SHALLOW STRIP OF WATER ABOUT 5 METERS WIDE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK AND DEPRESSION OF THE ROCK.  PROJECTING CLIFF OF THE POINT IS 11.0 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  FRENCHMANS CAP IS S 15 DEG W, E. TAN. ST. JAMES IS S 33 DEG E, HIGH PEAK ON THATCH CAY IS N 26 DEG W.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS NEAR THE EASTERN END OF THE ISLAND IN THE RED HOOK DISTRICT AT THE TOP OF BENNER HILL ON THE GROUNDS OF THE BENNER ESTATE.  TO REACH FROM CHARLOTTE AMALIE GO EAST ON HWY 30 PAST HAVENSIGHT, FRENCHMANS BAY, BOLONGO BAY AND BOVONI TO A T INTERSECTION IN THE VILLAGE OF NADIR.  AT THIS POINT TURN RIGHT ON HIGHWAY 32 AND PROCEED ABOUT 1.4 MI (2.3 KM) TO A CROSS ROADS AND A TRAFFIC LIGHT IN THE VILLAGE OF BENNER, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.6 MI (1.0 KM) TO A POINT WHERE THE MAIN ROAD MAKES A ZIG-ZAG RIGHT AND A CONTINUING DIRT ROAD TO THE RIGHT, TAKE THE DIRT ROAD TO A GATE, PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND FOLLOW THE DIM GRAVEL AND DIRT ROAD TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND A CONCRETE BUNKER ABOUT 20 FT (6.1 M) HIGH WITH THE STATION IN THE TOP CENTER OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE BUNKER.  THE STATION MARK IS A BRONZE DISK WITH A TRIANGLE ENCLOSED CENTERPUNCH EMBOSSED WITH THE LETTERS CADASTRAL SURVEY NO.  THE DESIGNATION OF THE STATION IS 97.  THIS STATION WAS KNOWN TO HAVE BEEN OCCUPIED DURING THE 1982 JOINT NOS, NGS, DMA DOPPLER SATELLITE SURVEY OF PUERTO RICO AND THE VIRGIN ISLANDS BUT NO DESCRIPTION OF THE STATION WAS AVAILABLE IN THE NGSIDB.                            STATION RECOVERY (2004)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COMPASSCOM INC 2004 (IR) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON HARRIS PEAK, THE HIGHEST HILL OF THE NW END OF ST. CROIX.  IT IS SITUATED ON SPRING GARDEN ESTATE.  THE ESTATE HOUSE LIES TO THE SW BUT IS HIDDEN FROM VIEW BY A RIDGE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE, OF THE NORTHERN OF A GROUP OF ROCKS LYING ON THE SW PART OF THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE ROCK LYING ON S EDGE OF THE HILLTOP AND ON THE W SIDE OF THE BASE OF THE LARGE TAMARIND TREE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A DEPRESSION OF ROCK OUTCROPPING ON THE WESTERN BREAK OF THE HILLTOP.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION AND R.M. 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION LIES ON THE HIGHEST PART OF HILL ON NW END OF ST. CROIX. SPRING GARDEN ESTATE HOUSE COULD NOT BE FOUND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE, IN THE NORTHERNMOST ROCK OF A GROUP OF ROCKS LYING ON SW PART OF HILL TOP.  TAMARIND TREE APPROXIMATELY 7 METER S.W. OF STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--3 MILES NORTHEAST OF FREDERIKSTED, ST. CROIX.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST HILL IN THE MIDDLE WESTERN PORTION OF ST. JOHN.  THE HILL IS KNOWN AS CAMELBERG PEAK.  MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT IN A LARGE ROCK ON THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF THE HILL.  THIS WAS AN OLD DANISH STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN ROCK TO THE NORTHWARD.  IT BEARS N 3 DEG 04 MIN E (TRUE) AND IS 5.78 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN ROCK.  IT BEARS S 60 DEG 56 MIN W (TRUE) AND IS 3.70 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  USED AS OFF-SHORE SIGNAL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CEG) STATION IS A ROUND-HEADED COPPER BOLT SET IN LARGE ROCK ON HIGHEST PART OF CAMELBURG PEAK.  THICK BRUSH UP TO 20 FEET IN HEIGHT SURROUNDS THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM CRUZ BAY, PROCEED E ON CENTER ROAD APPROXIMATELY 3-5/8 MILES TO A POINT 3/8 MILE PAST INTERSECTION LEADING TO THE S, AND 5/8 MILE PAST THE HAMMER FARM.  THIS POINT IS ON RIDGE TOP IMMEDIATELY N OF HILL MARKED ON MAP 1036 AND IS MARKED BY ARROW AND TRIANGLE CUT IN A 10-INCH-DIAMETER TREE AT ENTRANCE OF A TRAIL LEADING TO THE S AROUND THE W SIDE OF HILL 1036.  FOLLOW THIS TRAIL ALONG THE W SIDE OF HILL 1036 TO THE SADDLE IMMEDIATELY S OF IT.  THENCE PROCEED S ALONG RIDGE TOP BY FOLLOWING IRREGULAR ANIMAL TRAILS PAST HILL MARKED 1004 TO THE SUMMIT OF CAMELBURG PEAK.  CONSIDERABLE CUTTING WILL BE NECESSARY TO MAKE A SUITABLE TRAIL UP THE STEEP SLOPE.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRASS DISKS CEMENTED IN ROCKS.

markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION DECK IS ON THE EASTERN OF THE TWO PROMONTORIES THAT FORM THE OUTER TIP OF DECK POINT.  FRENCHMANS CAP SHOWS A LITTLE TO THE EASTWARD OF A LINE FROM THE STATION TO MIDWAY BETWEEN COW AND CALF ROCKS.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A CREVICE OF THE OUTCROP, 2 METERS FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  BUCK ISLAND LIGHT IS S 53 DEG 25 MIN 00 SEC W (TRUE) AND JAMES IS S 56 DEG 37 MIN 11 SEC E (TRUE).                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1971 (JKW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4 MILES SE OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1918 DESCRIPTION BY O.W.S. IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY WITH THE FOLLOWING ADDITION--  TO REACH BY VEHICLE, PROCEED ON DECK POINT ROAD TO THE SOUTHERN MOST HOUSE ON THE POINT WHICH IS OWNED BY MR. TORMEY.  WALK DOWN THE STEPPING STONES ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE HOUSE TO THE TOP OF A WOODEN STAIRWAY AND THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS ABOUT 6 FT. SOUTH OF THE TOP OF THE STAIRWAY AND ABOUT 50 FEET ABOVE THE WATER.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--0.4 MILE SOUTH OF COWPET BAY VILLAS.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION IS DESCRIBED IN BUOY LIST, 1925, U.S. LIGHTHOUSE SERVICE PAGE 19.  MAIN CHANNEL CHRISTIANSTED HARBOR.  GREAT MIDDLE GROUND REAR RANGE, ON AXIS OF CHANNEL BETWEEN GREAT MIDDLE GROUND AND ROUND REEF.  STRUCTURE IS LOCATED ON LONG REEF, 440 YARDS, W OF (SEE) FRONT BEACON.  STRUCTURE CONSISTS OF TWO WHITE TRIANGULAR DAYMARKS, APEX TO APEX, ON PYRAMIDAL CONCRETE BASE.  BEACON IS 50 FEET IN HEIGHT.  STATION IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY HALF MILE NORTHWESTWARD OF FORT LOUISA LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2008 (WEL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4.6 MI (7.4 KM) EAST OF CRUZ BAY WITHIN THE VIRGIN ISLANDS NATIONAL PARK, NEAR THE PARK RANGER RESIDENCE. OWNERSHIP--NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, 1300 CRUZ BAY CREEK, ST JOHN VI 00830, PHONE 340-776-6201.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CRUZ BAY, GO NORTHWEST FOR ABOUT 70 M (229.7 FT) ALONG MAIN STREET, THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.2 MI (0.3 KM) ON A STREET TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 10.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY, THEN SOUTHERLY FOR 8.1 MI (13.0 KM) TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 107.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY, THEN NORTHWESTERLY FOR 5.5 MI (8.8 KM) ON HIGHWAY 107 TO A RUIN ON LEFT AND A ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.15 MI (0.2 KM) TO THE END OF ROAD AT BORDEAUX MOUNTAIN TRAIL AND DIRT ROAD TO RANGER RESIDENCE ON RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR ABOUT 40 M (131.2 FT) TO THE STATION ON LEFT.   IT IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF BEDROCK, 43.4 M (142.4 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM THE FIRST COLUMN AT THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF PATIO AND 5.1 M (16.7 FT) SOUTH FROM THE CENTERLINE OF A DIRT ROAD.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE TOP OF DITTLESS POINT THAT RUNS OUT BETWEEN RENDEZVOUS BAY AND FISH BAY ON THE S SHORE OF ST. JOHN ISLAND.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 8 METERS N OF THE HIGHEST PART OF POINT AND IS 5 METERS W OF THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF FORMING A PROMINENT BIGHT IN THE E PART OF THE POINT.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK OF A ROCK OUTCROPPING 8 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK IN TOP OF LARGE ROCK LYING ON THE BREAK OF THE SLOPE TO THE NORTHWARD AND ABOUT THE MIDDLE OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER 3 FEET HIGH 3 FEET WIDE AND 5 FEET LONG, LYING ON THE W BREAK OF SLOPE OF RIDGE.  A REGULATION BRASS DISK BEARS N 5 DEG 14 MIN W AND IS 7.73 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  ANOTHER BEARS S 70 DEG 56 MIN W AND IS 6.46 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 2.88 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CEG) STATION IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A SMALL ROCK 8 METERS N OF THE HIGHEST PART OF DITLET POINT AND 5 METERS W OF THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF ON THE E SIDE OF THE POINT.  THERE IS VERY LIGHT BRUSH AROUND THE STATION.  TO REACH THE STATION, LAND BY SMALL BOAT AT E SIDE OF RENDEZVOUS BAY ON THE SAND BEACH THERE.  CROSS THE NARROW NECK OF DITLET POINT HERE AND PROCEED TO THE S ALONG E SLOPE OF DITLET POINT, THROUGH VERY LIGHT BRUSH TO THE STATION AT THE END OF THE POINT ATOP A PROMINENT ROCKY KNOLL.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRASS DISKS CEMENTED IN PROMINENT ROCKS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  DESCRIPTION BY C. E. G. 1946 IS ADEQUATE FORFUTURE RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION AND RM 1 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE STATION IS REACHED BY FOLLOWING A FOOTPATH ABOUT HALFWAY OUT TO DITLIF PT., THEN WALKING ALONG THE EASTERN SHORE AND RIDGETOP TO THE STATION.  ABOUT A 30 MINUTE PACK.  RM 2 WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR AT THIS TIME.  THE STATION WAS USED AS A CHECK ANGLE FOR STATION BAKE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABT. 2.5 MILES SE OF CRUZ BAY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF DOG ISLAND, WHICH LIES OFF THE SE END OF ST. THOMAS ISLAND.  NO TROUBLE SHOULD BE FOUND IN FINDING THE STATION.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED INTO THE BEDROCK.  A CAIRN OF ROCKS WAS PILED OVER THE MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A REGULATION BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED INTO A CRACK OF THE ROCK FORMING THE SHARP POINT AT THE TOP OF THE CLIFF.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) DESTROYED.  BEDROCK IN THIS AREA WAS FOUND TO BE BADLY ERODED.  THE STATION DISK WAS FOUND LYING LOOSE IN THE ERODED ROCKS AND WAS RETAINED BY THIS PARTY.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2.5 MILES S.E. OF COWPET BAY VILLAS, ST. THOMAS.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS SIGNAL IS ON THE WESTERN SIDE OF WATER ISLAND AND ON THE FIRST POINT S OF THE MOST SOUTHWESTERLY POINT OF DRIFT BAY.  IT IS A LOW ROCKY POINT.  THE TOP OF THE HILL AT MOSQUITO POINT IS IN RANGE WITH THE HIGHEST POINT OF CROWN HILL.  JUST TO THE SOUTHWARD OF THE STATION THERE IS A SMALL REEF WHICH TERMINATES IN TWO ROCKS THAT ARE AWASH AT LOW TIDE.  STATION IS ABOUT 8 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER AND IS ABOUT 13 METERS FROM HIGH WATER.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULAR BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN CREVICE OF THE ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISK IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER.  WITNESS MARK IS A BLAZE IN A TREE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  WITNESS MARK CUT INTO BARK OF TREE FACING STATION MARK, ASSISTED RECOVERY.  TRIANGULAR SECTION OF BARK CARVED OUT OF PROMINENT TREE ON THIS POINT OVERLOOKING TRIANGULATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  RM NOT RECOVERED.  STATION NOW LOCATED 97 FEET WEST OF SW CORNER OF HOUSE ON THE POINT.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON THE SANDY ISLAND ABOUT 100 METERS LONG AND 30 METERS WIDE LYING OFF COAKLEY BAY, N SIDE OF ST. CROIX.  THE N AND E SIDES OF THE ISLAND ARE PROTECTED BY A CORAL REEF.  IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO MARK THE STATION AS NO MARKS WOULD HAVE REMAINED IN THE SAND.  ELEVATION OF GROUND ABOUT 3 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION IS THE HIGHEST POINT OF WOODED PEAK USED AS HYDROGRAPHIC STATION.  NO ATTEMPT WAS MADE AT RECOVERY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  STATION IS THE HIGHEST POINT OF WOODED PEAK AND RECOVERED WITH THE USE OF A QUADRANGLE MAP.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF NANCY HILL, E END OF ST. JOHN ISLAND, WHICH IS THE HIGHEST HILL ON ST. JOHN ISLAND, E OF HERMITAGE OR HURRICANE HOLE.  MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT CEMENTED IN 0.4 BY 0.6-METER ROCK PROJECTING ABOUT 0.2 METER, 3 METERS W OF THE CENTER OF THE HILLTOP.  A CAIRN OF ROCKS WAS PLACED AROUND THE MARK.  THIS IS AN OLD DANISH STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1, A DRILL HOLE 0.3 METER IN DIAMETER AND 0.04 METER DEEP IN SLOPING FACE OF ROCK, 0.07 METER IN DIAMETER.  ARROW 0.01 METER WIDE AND 0.2 METER LONG CUT IN ROCK POINTS TOWARD THE STATION.  THE ROCK LIES ON THE N EDGE OF THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN CRACK OF ROCK 0.2 METER WIDE AND 0.4 METER LONG LYING IN MIDDLE OF THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 3, A CROSS WITH 0.10 BY 0.17-METER ARMS CUT 0.01 METER DEEP IN 0.5 METER DIAMETER ROCK LYING ON WESTERN EDGE OF THE HILLTOP.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT EAST POINT ON THE MOST EASTERLY POINT OF ST CROIX ON THE NORTH EASTERLY EDGE OF TRACK ROAD LOOP.  THE MARK IS AT THE MOST EASTERLY POINT OF ST CROIX.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED---EAST POINT 1980---, CEMENTED IN TOP OF A MASS OF CONCRETE 4 CM BELOW GROUND SURFACE. IT IS LOCATED 5.9 METERS (16.4 FT) EAST-NORTHEAST FROM NORTHEAST EDGE OF ROAD AND 28.4 METERS (93.2 FT) NORTHEAST FROM NORTHEAST CONER FENCE POST OF FENCE AROUND WEATHER STATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.4 METERS.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1900 (WCH) A LOW WHITE STRUCTURE AT THE POINT ON THE E SIDE OF THE ENTRANCE TO THE HARBOR.                            STATION RECOVERY (1918)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS TOP CENTER OF LIGHT HOUSE, KNOWN HITHERTO AS ST. THOMAS LIGHT HOUSE, LOCATED AT THE SE APPROACH OF ST. THOMAS HARBOR, MAIN SHORE LINE ON WHAT WAS FORMERLY KNOWN AS MYHLSNFELDTS POINT, BUT WHICH IS NOW GENERALLY CALLED EAST POINT.  THE ELEVATION OF THE TOP AS DETERMINED BY TOPOGRAPHY IS 115 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1928)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1928 (FTS) NO CHANGES IN DESCRIPTION EXCEPT THAT THE LIGHT IS FREQUENTLY CALLED ANY OF THE THREE NAMES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) LIGHT HAS BEEN REMOVED.  STRUCTURE STILL IN PLACE.  A MOTEL HAS BEEN BUILT NEAR STRUCTURE.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT EAST POINT ON THE MOST EASTERLY POINT OF ST CROIX ON THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE DIRT ROAD JUST BEFORE THE LOOP AT EAST POINT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM CHRISTIANSTED GO EAST ALONG THE ROAD RUNNING ALONG THE NORTH SHORELINE TO CRAMER PARK. CONTINUE EAST ON DIRT ROAD TO EAST POINT WHERE THE ROAD ENDS AS A LOOP.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED---EAST POINT RM 1 1980---, CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A IRREGULAR MASS OF CONCRETE, 10 CM UNDER GROUND. IT IS LOCATED 7.4 METERS (24.3 FT) WEST FROM CENTER OF ROAD FORK, 4.0 METERS (13.1 FT) SOUTH FROM CENTERLINE OF EASTWEST TRACK ROAD AND 16.5 METERS (54.1 FT) EAST FROM CENTER OF LARGE LONE CACTUS ON SOUTHERN ROAD EDGE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.4 METERS.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE SOUTHWESTERN POINT OF BOOBY CAY.  THIS CAY IS ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF COCKROACH ISLAND AND SEPARATED FROM IT BY A NARROW STRIP OF WATER.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN THE ROCK NEARBY, BUT NO ANGLES OR DISTANCES WERE MEASURED TO IT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (GCM) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION WAS FOUND.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2008 (WEL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3.9 MI (6.3 KM) EAST-NORTHEAST OF CRUZ BAY.  OWNERSHIP--ROAD RIGHT-OF-WAY.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CRUZ BAY, GO NORTHWEST FOR ABOUT 70 M (229.7 FT) ALONG MAIN STREET, THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.2 MI (0.3 KM) ON A STREET TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 10.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 5.3 MI (8.5 KM) ON HIGHWAY 10 TO THE STATION ON RIGHT, ABOUT 0.05 MI (0.1 KM) PAST THE JUNCTION OF BORDEAUX MOUNTAIN ROAD.   IT IS SET IN A CONCRETE WING WALL OF A STORM DRAIN, 11.1 M (36.4 FT) SOUTH FROM THE NORTH END OF A GUARDRAIL, 7.4 M (24.3 FT) NORTH FROM A UTILITY POLE, 4.3 M (14.1 FT) EAST FROM THE CENTERLINE OF THE HIGHWAY, 2.8 M (9.2 FT) SOUTH FROM A ROAD SIGN, 0.8 M (2.6 FT) WEST FROM THE EAST END OF WING WALL AND 0.5 M (1.6 FT) NORTH FROM A GUARDRAIL POST.
