markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON MT. FANCY, S SHORE OF ST. CROIX.  THIS IS A CONSPICUOUS HILL FORMING THE EASTERN POINT OF GREAT POND BAY.  IT IS SW OF COTTON GROVE ESTATE BUILDINGS.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST TIP OF THE WESTERN OF THE TWO HILLS FORMING MOUNT FANCY.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK IN 6-INCH DIAMETER CEMENT POST PROJECTING ABOUT 4 INCHES.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN 1-METER DIAMETER ROCK OUTCROPPING 1-1/2 METERS ON ITS W SIDE AND 1/2 METER ON ITS E SIDE.  THE ROCK LIES ALONGSIDE THE N AND S FENCE LINE MARKING E BOUNDARY OF GREAT POND ESTATE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN DEPRESSION OF 1 METER ROCK OUTCROPPING 0.3 METER, APPROXIMATELY 4 METERS S OF TIPTOP OF THE RIDGE JOINING THE TWO HILLS.  NO DISTANCES OR DIRECTIONS TO REFERENCE MARKS WERE MEASURED.  TOP OF POLE - 2.93 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED, AND IS OCCUPIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) NOT VISITED.  USED HILL FOR OFF-SHORE WORK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1919.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT FOUND AND ARE PRESUMED DESTROYED.  A TO REACH FOLLOWS--  FROM THE DOCK AREA IN CHRISTIANSTED, FOLLOW THE MAIN ROAD EAST FOR 1.25 MILES TO A PAVED SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT ON WINDING PAVED ROAD AND CONTINUE SOUTHEASTERLY FOR 1.75 MILES TO A PAVED SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 0.75 MILE TO A THREE-WAY INTERSECTION.  TURN RIGHT, SOUTHERLY, AND FOLLOW PAVED ROAD FOR 1.45 MILES TO A DIRT SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW ROAD UPHILL FOR 0.1 MILE TO A PRIVATE DRIVE.  CONTINUE 0.05 MILE TO A HOUSE AND END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE PACK UPHILL AND NORTHERLY TO HIGHEST PART OF HILL AND STATION, ABOUT 20 FEET WEST OF A NORTH-SOUTH FENCELINE.  THE MARK PROJECTS 4 INCHES AND IS SURROUNDED BY ROCKS.  A 5 MINUTE PACK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 4.6 MI. SOUTHEAST OF CHRISTIANSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THERE IS NOW A ROAD LEADING AROUND TO THE SOUTHWEST SIDE OF MT FANCY, TO THE RESIDENCE OF MRS. ANN WINTER, AND A GOOD TRAIL ON THE EAST SIDE OF HOUSE TO THE TOP OF HILL AND STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. A METAL FENCE POST WAS DRIVEN INTO THE ROCKS ONE FOOT NORTH OF THE STATION AT THE PROPERTY OWNERS REQUEST.THE PROPERTY OWNER SAID THAT A FIRE BREAK WAS GOING TO BE CUT ACROSS THE TOP OF THE HILL WITH A BULL DOZIER THIS YEAR. THE PROPERTY OWNER SHOULD BE CONTACTED PRIOR TO GOING TO STATION. MS. ANN WINTER, HOME,773 1337, WORK,ST CROIX 773 0440. WORK, ST THOMAS, 774 2300.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN PREFABRICATED CONCRETE POST IMBEDDED IN GROUND
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) MAIN SCHEME STATION FLAG IS ON WHAT IS CALLED FLAGHILL.  THE HILL IS A PROMINENT ONE ON THE E SIDE OF ST. THOMAS HARBOR.  THE STATION IS ON THE MIDDLE OF THE SUMMIT RIDGE AND ABOUT 50 METERS W OF THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HILL.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER.  A CAIRN OF ROCKS WAS PILED AROUND THE BOULDER.  THE BOULDER IS APPROXIMATELY 0.5 METER IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTS APPROXIMATELY 0.5 METER ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED INTO A CRACK ON THE SIDE OF A BOULDER ON THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER ON THE N SIDE OF THE RIDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (JMC) A TWO HOUR SEARCH OF THE AREA WAS MADE BUT DUE TO TALL GRASS AND MANY ROCKS THE STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED.  TOP OF HILL HAS BEEN LEVELED OFF AND TOP OF HILL REFRESHMENT BAR BUILT.  A TRAMWAY RUNS TO TOP WHICH IS BEST WAY TO REACH TOP OF HILL.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED ON ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS IN THE SOUTHEAST CENTRAL PART OF THE ISLAND JUST SOUTHEAST OF THE SOUTHEAST EDGE OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE AND ABOUT 1 MI (1.6 KM) NORTHEAST OF MUHLENFELS POINT AND THE FRENCHMANS REEF RESORT AT THE TOP OF FLAG HILL.  THE OBJECT IS A STEEL MAST/TOWER AND THE POINT INTERSECTED IS THE CENTER OF THE TOWER.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2005 (KEN) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE NE END OF THE TREELESS RIDGE THAT RUNS OUT TO THE NE FROM THE MAIN PART OF THE ISLAND OF FLANNAGAN.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK ABOUT THE MIDDLE OF A CONSPICUOUS FLAT-TOPPED, 3-METER DIAMETER ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK 0.3 METER FROM EASTERN SIDE OF ROCK.  IT IS 1.642 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN WIDENED CRACK ON TOP OF ROUNDED OUTCROPPING ROCK 2 METERS IN DIAMETER, LYING TO THE NORTHWARD.  IT IS 12.13 METER DISTANT FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1924)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) NO ATTEMPT MADE AT RECOVERY.  SIGNAL VISIBLE FROM SOME DISTANCE OFF.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION NOT RECOVERABLE.  NO EVIDENCE OF MARKING.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE S SHORE OF THE ISLAND OF ST. THOMAS OFF THE WESTERNMOST END OF FORTUNA BAY.  STATION IS NEAR THE OUTERMOST EDGE OF A LARGE OFF SHORE ROCK.  A VERY NARROW PASSAGE ABOUT 10 FEET WIDE WITH DEEP WATER SEPARATING THIS ROCK FROM THE MAINLAND.  IN APPROACHING THE POINT, THE ROCK APPEARS AS PART OF THE MAINLAND.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 8 FEET FROM THE WATER LINE AND ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER MARK.  SAIL ROCK IS S 58 DEG W MAGNETIC FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--MILES WEST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION FORTUNA FOUND AS DESCRIBED BY O.W.S. IN 1918.  THIS STATION CAN ONLY BE REACHED BY SKIFF AND LANDING SHOULD BE ATTEMPTED FROM LEEWARD ONLY IN CALM WEATHER WITH VERY LITTLE SWELL RUNNING.  LANDING IS DIFFICULT BUT CAN BE DONE IN PERIODS OF CALM AS IT IS ALMOST COMPLETELY EXPOSED TO SEAS AND WINDS.  WATER IS SHOAL OFFSHORE OF THIS STATION SO CARE SHOULD BE EXERCISED IN ATTEMPTING A LANDING.  STATION IS 0.2 MILES WEST OF DAVID POINT.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5.4 MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2008 (WEL) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1.6 MI (2.6 KM) EAST-NORTHEAST OF CRUZ BAY, IN EXPOSED ROCK OUTCROP BETWEEN ENTRANCE DRIVE AND PARKING LOT OF THE MYRA KEATING SMITH HEALTH CENTER.  OWNERSHIP--MYRA KEATING SMITH HEALTH CENTER.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN CRUZ BAY, GO NORTHWEST FOR ABOUT 70 M (229.7 FT) ALONG MAIN STREET, THEN TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.2 MI (0.3 KM) ON A STREET TO THE JUNCTION OF HIGHWAY 10.  TURN LEFT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 2.0 MI (3.2 KM) ON HIGHWAY 10 TO A PAVED ENTRANCE TO THE HEALTH CENTER ON LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH AND THEN WEST FOR ABOUT 70 M (229.7 FT) ON THE ENTRANCE ROAD TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.   IT IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A ROCK OUTCROP, 40.8 M (133.9 FT) NORTHEAST FROM THE WESTERN MOST STREET LIGHT, 35.6 M (116.8 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A STREET LIGHT, 20.6 M (67.6 FT) SOUTHWEST FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF A HELIPAD, 12.3 M (40.4 FT) SOUTH OF THE GUARDRAIL OF A PARKING LOT AND 9.8 M (32.2 FT) NORTH FROM THE CENTERLINE OF THE ROAD.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON APPROXIMATELY THE HIGHEST TIP OF THE KNOLL ON WHICH FREDENSBORG ESTATE HOUSE STANDS.  THIS KNOLL IS THE NORTHERN END OF THE RIDGE KNOWN AS KINGS HILL.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 20 METERS FROM THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE HILLTOP.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL ROCK OUTCROPPING 5 CENTIMETERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A SIMILAR DISK CEMENTED IN ROCK LYING FLUSH WITH THE GROUND ON SLOPE TO THE S.  A TREE STANDS IN LINE BETWEEN STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SIMILAR DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ONE OF A CLUSTER OF ROCKS LYING 2 METERS FROM THE N EDGE OF HILLTOP.  A BOULDER 1 METER IN DIAMETER LIES ALONGSIDE OF THE REFERENCE MARK AND TO THE NW OF IT.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK LYING ON THE NORTHERN BREAK OF THE HILLTOP.  TOP OF POLE - 8.50 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION WAS NOT FOUND AFTER A THOROUGH SEARCH DUE TO HEAVY OVERGROWTH.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 5.5 MI. WEST OF CHRISTIANSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION GAS IS ON GAS ISLAND IN THE ENTRANCE TO JERSEY BAY, 3.5 MILES E OF EAST POINT LIGHT.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PINNACLE OF THE ISLAND.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE OF CONSPICUOUS OUTCROP.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DEPRESSION OF OUTCROPPING LEDGE, BEARS N 46 DEG E (MAGNETIC) AND IS 4.27 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION AND REFERENCE MARK RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1918 DESCRIPTION BY O.W.S. REQUIRES REVISION AS FOLLOWS--  STATION GAS IS ON CAS CAY IN THE ENTRANCE TO JERSEY BAY, 1.1 MILE W.S.W. OF DECK POINT.  THE STATION IS NEAR THE EAST END AND ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND.  BOTH THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARK DISKS ARE UNSTAMPED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4.6 MILE S.E. OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (2008)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2008 MARK LOCATED ON ROCK SURROUNDED BY WATER NEAR THE NORTH END OF MAGENS BAY BEACH.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN UNSPECIFIED ROCK OR BOULDER
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON HIGHEST TIP OF THE 867-FOOT GRASS-COVERED HILL CALLED SIGNAL HILL, ON THE WESTERN END OF THE ISLAND 1.5 MILES E OF FREDERIKSTED.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK IN THE TOP OF A 6-INCH DIAMETER CEMENT POST 18 INCHES LONG PLANTED WITH ITS TOP FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL ROCK OUTCROPPING ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE HILLTOP 4 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SIMILAR MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN DEPRESSION OF A SMALL ROCK OUTCROPPING ON THE SW BREAK OF THE HILLTOP.  TOP OF POLE - 5.80 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION IS DESTROYED DUE TO CONSTRUCTION OF A NAVY ANTENNA SITE. THE U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE HAS ESTABLISHED THEIR STATION GEORGE ABOUT 300 FEET SOUTH ON A LOWER PART OF THE HILL.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 1.9 MI. NORTHEAST OF FREDERIKSTED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF GIFT HILL, SOMETIMES CALLED SESSMAN HILL.  MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT CEMENTED IN A SMALL LOW ROCK.  THIS WAS AN OLD DANISH STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DEPRESSION OF LARGE ROCK.  IT BEARS S 88 DEG 22 MIN W (TRUE) AND IS 7.96 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DEPRESSION IN ROCK.  IT BEARS N 9 DEG 15 MIN W (TRUE) AND IS 3.54 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CFG) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF GIFT HILL, SOMETIMES CALLED SESSMAN HILL.  IT IS A COPPER BOLT CEMENTED IN LOW ROCK ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE THE GROUND.  SMALL ROCKS HAVE BEEN PLACED ALL AROUND THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 ARE STANDARD BRASS DISKS IN LARGE BOULDERS.  APPROXIMATELY 90 FEET S OF GIFT IS A SMALL CORRUGATED-METAL HOUSE WITH RED ROOF, BELONGING TO A WOMAN BY THE NAME OF CATHLEEN HOWELL.  FROM CRUZ BAY, FOLLOW CENTER ROAD FOR APPROXIMATELY 2 MILES TO POINT WHERE TRAIL LEADS OFF IN DIRECTION OF GIFT HILL (CONSULT MAP OF ST. JOHN).  FOLLOW THIS TRAIL, WHICH BEARS ALMOST TRUE S FROM CENTER ROAD, FOR ABOUT 3/4 MILE TO HIGHEST POINT IN ELEVATION.  LEAVE MAIN TRAIL AND FOLLOW PATH WHICH LEADS LEFT OF E.  LOW GIFT HILL WILL BE REACHED IN A COUPLE OF HUNDRED FEET.  CONTINUE ACROSS INTO SADDLE BETWEEN LOW GIFT AND HIGH GIFT HILL.  IN THE MIDDLE OF THE SADDLE IS A FRAME HOUSE BELONGING TO ROBERT BASTIN.  (CONTACT BASTIN FOR LOCATION OF STATION).  CONTINUE BEYOND THIS HOUSE THROUGH GATE FOR ANOTHER 600 FEET TO THE TOP OF HIGH GIFT HILL.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION MARK, WHICH IS A COPPER BOLT, AND R.M. NO. 2 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  R.M. NO. 1 NOT SEARCHED FOR.  STATION MAY BE REACHED BY JEEP.  TO REACH FROM CRUZ BAY, PROCEED ABOUT 2 MILES ON CENTERLINE ROAD TO THE PUBLIC WORKS GARAGE AND A CONCRETE ROAD LEADING SOUTH.  GO SOUTH ON THIS ROAD WHICH BECOMES A DIRT ROAD FOR ABOUT ONE MILE TO THE TOP OF GIFT HILL AND THE END OF THE ROAD.  STATION IS ABOUT 125 FEET EAST OF THE HOUSE AT THE END OF THE ROAD.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1.5 MILE E.S.E. OF CRUZ BAY, ST. JOHN.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION AND RM 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AND AS DESCRIBED.  RM 1 WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR AT THIS TIME.  THE STATION WAS USED AS A CHECK ANGLE FOR STATION BAKE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABT. 1.5 MILES ESE OF CRUZ BAY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON HIGHEST TIP OF GOAT HILL, E END OF ST. CROIX ISLAND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION MARK CEMENTED IN SMALL BOULDER BURIED IN THE GROUND AND SURROUNDED WITH ROCKS.  NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE PUT IN AS THEY WERE LEFT FOR THE OBSERVING PARTY TO PUT IN.  BEST WAY OF REACHING THE TOP IS FROM THE S SIDE.  NO OBSERVATIONS TAKEN ON THE STATION OR AT THE STATION.  A 3 BY 3 POLE ERECTED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  NO REFERENCE MARKS PLACED BY THIS PARTY AS DIFFICULTY IN PLACING NOT WARRANTING USE OF FURTHER TIME AT STATION.  STATION IS OCCUPIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION WAS NOT VISITED, IT IS USED FOR OFF-SHORE WORK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1975 SEARCHED FOR, BUT NOT FOUND.  A ROAD HAS BEEN BULLDOZED (PROBABLY DURING WW II) TO EXTREME E. END OF TOP OF HILL.  STATION PROBABLY DESTROYED.  A NEW STATION TAM 1975 WAS ESTABLISHED BY NAVOCEANO IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY OF THE PRESUMED LOCATION OF GOAT.  STATION TAM IS MARKED WITH A 1/2 INCH DIAMETER IRON ROD IN A 6 INCH HIGH STONE CAIRN CEMENTED WITH PERMATEX.  TWO 3-1/2 INCH DIAMETER BRONZE DISK U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET IN CONCRETE PAD EYES TO REFERENCE TAM.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION NOT RECOVERED, BELIEVED DESTROYED DUE TO THE CONSTRUCTION OF A NAVY ANTENNA SITE, NOW DISMANTLED.  A U.S. NAVY OCEANOGRAPHIC STATION, TAM 1975, AND TWO REFERENCE MARKS ARE ESTABLISHED ABOUT 30 YARDS EAST OF THE SITE OF GOAT, ON THE EASTERNMOST END OF THE HILLTOP.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 8.6 MILES EAST OF CHRISTIANSTED.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON THE POINT BETWEEN GRAPE TREE BAY AND TURNERS HOLE, S SIDE NEAR THE E END OF THE ISLAND.  THE STATION IS ON THE SLOPING SHALE ROCK OF THE MOST S PART OF THE POINT.  IT IS ABOUT 20 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A SMALL MASS OF CEMENT IN A DEPRESSION OF THE ROCK.  NO OBSERVATIONS MADE ON THE SIGNAL.  BANNER ON 2 BY 4 POLE ERECTED OVER STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  INTERSECTION STATION BY THIS PARTY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1975 SEARCHED FOR, BUT NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED AT GRAPETREE BAY ON THE SOUTH EAST SIDE OF ST CROIX. IT IS ON THE PROPERTY OF THE GRAPETREE BEACH HOTEL. MR. CROSS IS THE PRESENT MANAGER OF THE HOTEL.  TO REACH HROM THE GRAPETREE BEACH HOTEL ON THE WEST SIDE OF GRAPETREE BAY GO EAST ON MAIN ROAD FOR 1.7 KM (1.05 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND GUARD SHACK, TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) TO A T INTERSECTION. TURN RIGHT AND GO WESTERLY FOR 15 METERS (50 FT) TO A SIDEROAD LEFT AND STATION IN OPEN FIELD ON LEFT.  THE STATION IS A NOS ALUMINUM DISK STAMPED---GRAPETREE 1982--- SECURED TO THE TOP OF A 1.1 METER (42 IN) ALUMINUM ROD EMBEDED IN CONCRETE, FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED, 44.0 METERS (144.5 FT) NORTHWEST FROM THE DOOR ON ROOM A 6, 43.6 METERS (143.0 FT) NORTH FROM THE HIGH WATER LINE, 13.7 METERS (45.0 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A PALM TREE, 23.2 METERS (76.0 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A LAMP POST.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.3 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.
markers.setting: undefinedSET INTO TOP OF METAL PIPE DRIVEN INTO GROUND
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON HIGHEST TIP OF NORTHERLY KNOLL OF GREEN CAY.  THIS CAY LIES TO THE EASTWARD OF THE ENTRANCE TO CHRISTIANSTED HARBOR.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN THE OUTCROPPING LEDGE FORMING TOP OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK ON E SIDE OF RIDGE AND ABOUT 25 FEET BELOW THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN ROCK ON SE SIDE OF THE KNOLL AND ABOUT 15 FEET BELOW THE STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN LARGE ROCK OF THE RIDGE FORMING THE BACKBONE OF THE ISLAND.  IT LIES ON THE N END OF THE RIDGE ABOUT 5 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION.  TOP OF POLE - 4.55 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED, AND IS OCCUPIED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE NORTH END OF GREEN CAY. THERE IS A HIGHER POINT ON THE SOUTH END OF THE KEY. THIS ISLAND IS COVERED WITH LOW SCRUB (STICKER BUSHES) AND OFFERS GOOD VISIBILITY IN ALL DIRECTIONS EXCEPT TO THE SOUTH-SOUTHWEST WHICH IS BLOCKED BY THE HIGHER PART OF THE ISLAND.  A BOAT LANDING WAS MADE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ISLAND 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) SOUTH OF THE MOST NORTHERLY POINT, DUE TO THE REEF AROUND THE ISLAND WAIST DEEP WATER WAS WADDED, EXTREME CARE IS ADVISED. THE BEST ROUTE TO THE STATION AT THIS TIME WAS BY PACKING ARROUND A ROCKY POINT ON THE NORTHWEST SIDE THENCE UPHILL TO STATION.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN 1.5 METERS.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS STATION IS NEAR THE NW CORNER OF A SMALL GRASSY ISLAND KNOWN AS GREEN CAY.  STATION IS NEAR THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE ISLAND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN AN OUTCROPPING ROCK ABOUT 2 METERS FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  A REFERENCE MARK WAS CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF THE CLIFF.  OWING TO THE SHOAL WATER SURROUNDING THIS ISLAND AND THE FACT THAT ITS SHORES ARE ROCKY, THE LANDING IS VERY DIFFICULT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION GREEN WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  IT IS PRESUMED TO HAVE ERODED AWAY.  REFERENCE MARK WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED, BUT IT TOO IS IS DANGER OF BEING LOST TO EROSION.  DISTANCE AND AZIMUTH TO STATION FROM RM IS NOT GIVEN IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  STATION IS SUPPOSED TO BE ON GREEN CAY 0.1 MILE OFFSHORE OF ST. THOMAS.  TO REACH GREEN CAY, A SKIFF MUST BE USED, AND LANDING ATTEMPTED FROM WESTERN SIDE OF ISLAND IN PERIODS OF CALM.  SKIFF MUST BE BROUGHT IN CLOSE TO SHORE AND PARTY SHOULD WADE IN TO PREVENT SWAMPING OR DAMAGE TO SKIFF BY SWELLS AND ROCKS.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2.3 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE, ST. THOMAS.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE MOUTH OF THE SALT RIVER BAY ON THE EAST END OF A POINT.  TO REACH FROM THE JUNCTION OF NORTH SHORE ROAD AND SCENIC ROAD GO NORTHERLY ON NORTH SHORE ROAD FOR 2.1 KM (1.3 MI)TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT A MARINA, TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.7 KM (0.45 MI) TO THE END OF ROAD AT BEACH, PACK EAST ALONG BEACH FOR APPROXIMATELY 200 FT TO THE POINT AND STATION.  THE STATION IS A NOS BRASS DISK STAMPED---GREIG HILL POINT 1982---, CEMENTED IN A DEPRESSION IN BEDROCK, APPROXIMATELY 3 FT ABOVE WATER.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.6 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.

markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. IT IS LOCATED ON PROPERTY CONTROLED BY THE U.S. NAVY AND AN ESCORT IS REQUIRED TO ACCESS THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHWEST END OF ST CROIX, AT HAMS BLUFF ON THE HAMS BLUFF LIGHTHOUSE CATWALK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FREDERIKSTED PIER GO EAST FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 6.7 KM (4.2 MI) TO A FORK, SCENIC ROAD, KEEP LEFT, NORTHERLY FOR 1.3 KM (0.8 MI) TO THE ENTRANCE OF NAVY INSTULATION (AN EXCORT FROM THIS INSTULATION IS REQUIRED TO GO ON TO THE STATION).  PASS TO THE LEFT OF MAIN BUILDING TO A SECOND BUILDING PASS TO THE LEFT OF THIS BUILDING THROUGH GULLY AND UP MOUNTAIN SWITHBACK ROAD FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO LIGHTHOUSE AND STATION. A 4 WHEEL DRIVE JEEP IS RECOMENDED FOR THE LAST MILAGE TO STATION.  THE STATION IS A CHISLED TRIANGLE WITH PUNCH MARK IN STEEL GRATING, STAMPED---HAMS LH ECC---, STATION NAME IS STAMPED INTO ONE FLAT IRON PIECE OF THE CATWALK. IT IS LOCATED ON NORTH SIDE OF CATWALK AROUND TOP OF LIGHTHOUSE OPPOSITE CATWALK ENTRANCE DOOR AND 0.64 METERS EAST OF A LIGHTPOST ON CATWALK AND 0.307 METERS FROM OUTER WALL OF LIGHTHOUSE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHWEST END OF ST CROIX ON THE FIRST POINT NORTH OF HAMS BAY, 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) WEST OF THE HAMS BLUFF LIGHTHOUSE, 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) NORTHEAST OF THE REBECCAS PRIDE RESORT, ENTRANCE.  STATION IS UNDER AN OBSERVATION PLATFORM.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FREDERIKSTED MUNICIPAL PIER, GO EAST FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSS STREET.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON MAIN ROAD FOR 6.7 KM (4.2 MI) TO A FORK, SCENIC ROAD,  KEEP LEFT FORK AND GO 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO BEACH AND STATION.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD USN DISK STAMPED---HAMS 1975---, CEMENTED IN A MASS OF CONCRETE IN A POCKET OF THE ROCK BENEATH AN OBSERVATION PLATFORM SUPPORTED BY 4 CONCRETE COLUMNS. IT IS LOCATED 11 METERS (52.5 FT) SOUTH FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF ROCKY SHORELINE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 4 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (2007)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS 2007 (HI) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS SIGNAL IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHERNMOST POINT OF THE ISLAND OF HANS LOLLIK, WHICH LIES ABOUT 2 MILES OFF THE N SHORE OF ST. THOMAS.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF A LONG ROCKY LEDGE THAT IS SEPARATED FROM THE MAINLAND BY A NARROW PASSAGE ABOUT 20 FEET WIDE.  THE LEDGE IS APPROXIMATELY 20 FEET WIDE AND 100 FEET LONG.  THE LEDGE RUNS IN A GENERAL NORTHEAST AND SOUTHWESTERLY DIRECTION.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK WEDGED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A FLAT PART OF THE ROCK.  THIS ROCK IS THE ONLY ONE IN THE VICINITY AND THERE SHOULD BE NO DIFFICULTY IN RECOVERING IT.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 20 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER.  FROM THE CENTER HANS LOLLIK ROCK, IS IN RANGE WITH THE HIGHEST PEAK OF THATCH CAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THIS STATION IS A REGULATION TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN TOP OF NORTHERN CORNER OF OLD BATTERY RUINS (SHIPLEYS BATTERY), LOCATED ON NORTHERN KNOLL OF HASSEL ISLAND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS REGULATION STANDARD BRONZE DISK ON TOP OF WALL TO THE S.  IT BEARS S 12 DEG 31 MIN W (TRUE), AND IS 13.1 METERS DISTANT FROM STATION.  ELEVATION BY TOPOGRAPHY 210 FEET.  ELEVATION BY TRIANGULATION 207 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  THE REFERENCE MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR BRIEFLY BUT NOT FOUND DUE TO HEAVY VEGETATION ON TOP OF THE BATTERY WALL.  THE STATION IS BEST REACHED BY TAKING THE ROYAL MAIL BOAT FERRY, WHICH RUNS BETWEEN CHARLOTTE AMALIE AND HASSEL IS. FROM THE LANDING ON HASSEL IS., WALK SOUTHERLY PAST THE HOUSES, THEN FOLLOW A FOOTPATH UPHILL TO A CATCHMENT BASIN.  FROM HERE FOLLOW A DIM TRAIL TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION IN THE BATTERY WALL.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ON THE NORTH END OF HASSEL IS., IN CHARLOTTE AMALIE HARBOR.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE EXTREME EASTERLY END OF POINT THAT SEPARATES HAUL OVER BAY AND MENNBECK BAY (LOCALLY KNOWN AS JACOBS BAY).  IMMEDIATELY BEHIND AND ABOUT 10 FEET AWAY FROM STATION RISES A BOLD CLIFF OF JAGGED WEATHERED ROCK ABOUT 40 FEET HIGH.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN LARGE STEEP SIDED ROCK ON EXTREME EDGE OF POINT.  STATION IS ABOUT 6 FEET ABOVE THE WATER LINE.  EASTERLY POINT OF LITTLE THATCH ISLAND SHOWS JUST OUTSIDE OF POINT W OF JACOBS BAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE CENTRAL AREA OF ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS ABOUT 1 MILE (1.6 KM) NORTH OF THE ST THOMAS AIRPORT.  THE STATION IS A MICROWAVE TOWER WITH A PROMINENT WHITE FLASHING STROBE AT ITS TOP LOCATED ON HAWK HILL.  THIS WAS AT THE TIME OF THE SURVEY THE ONLY STROBE LIGHTED LANDMARK IN ST THOMAS AND IS VISIBLE FOR LONG DISTANCES ESPECIALLY AT NIGHT DUE TO THE HIGH INTENSITY OF THE STROBE.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2005 (KEN) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2007 UNITED STATES VIRGIN ISLANDS, ISLAND AND COUNTY OF SAINT THOMAS, SOUTH CENTRAL SAINT THOMAS IN THE PORT CITY OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE ON THE CAMPUS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF THE VIRGIN ISLANDS.   STARTING FROM THE UNITED STATES COAST GUARD STATION IN CHARLOTTE AMALIE, AT THE INTERSECTION OF PORT PLADSON AND HIGHWAY 30, GO 2.5 MI (4.0 KM) WESTERLY ALONG HIGHWAY 30 TO THE CYRIL E.KING AIRPORT FIRE STATION ON THE LEFT, AND TAKE THE BACK CAMPUS ROAD RIGHT GOING 0.25 MI (0.4 KM) TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT ATOP A MASSIVE PYRAMIDAL SEMAPHORE ROUGHLY 4 FT (1.2 M) BY 4 FT.   THE MARK IS 44.4 M (145.7 FT) NORTHWEST OF THE NORTH CORNER OF A DRIVEWAY, 18.3 M (60.0 FT) SOUTHWEST OF A UTILITY STREET LAMP, 8.1 M (26.6 FT) SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTERLINE OF ANOTHER SEMAPHORE, 7.1 M (23.3 FT) WEST OF THE STREET CENTERLINE IN LINE WITH THE SOUTH EDGE OF A SPEED BUMP, 1.5 M (4.9 FT) ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE ROAD.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN A LARGE STRUCTURE WITH FOUNDATIONS ON BEDROCK
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE ROCKY POINT RUNNING TO THE SW FROM THE HEAD OF HURRICANE HOLE AND KNOWN AS LONG OR MARDENBOROUGH POINT.  THE POINT IS COMPOSED OF REDDISH YELLOW ROCKS, WHICH EXTEND DOWN TO THE WATER FROM A GRASSY HEADLAND.  STATION IS ABOUT 5 METERS FROM THE END OF THE POINT AND ABOUT 1 METER FROM ITS S EDGE.  IT IS ABOUT 3 METERS ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  MARKED BY A U. S. C. AND G. S. BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A CREVICE OF THE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE PROPERTY OF HESS OIL ON THE EAST JETTY. IT IS ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE ROAD AT THE BEGGING OF THR TURN AROUND. PERMISSION WILL HAVE TO BE PREARRANGED TO ACCESS THIS STATION.  TO REACH FROM THE ST CROIX AIRPORT GO EAST THEN NORTH FOR 1.6 KM (1.0 MI) TO A CROSSROAD AT STOPLIGHT. TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON NEW HIGHWAY FOR 2.7 KM (1.7 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT FOLLOWING ALONG FENCE ON WINDING ROAD FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) TO MAIN GATE OF HESS OIL.FROM MAIN GATE ESCROT WILL SHOW TO REACH EAST JETTY.  THE STATION IS A BRASS DISKSTAMPED---C 51.50 ELV 18.26 L 862.50--- SET IN A 12 INCH SQUARE MONUMENT IN THE CENTER OF THREE 6 INCH PIPES PROJECTING THREE FEET.  IT IS LOCATED, 7.7 METERS (25.2 FT) EAST FROM CENTERLINE OF ROAD, 5.0 METERS (16.4 FT) WEST FROM EAST EDGE OF ASPHALT.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.6 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.
markers.setting: undefinedSET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE S SHORE OF ST. THOMAS ISLAND ON A PROMINENT POINT ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN BLACK POINT AND LUCAS POINT.  STATION IS ON A HIGH DETACHED ROCK.  THE TOP OF THE ROCK IS ABOUT 40 FEET ABOVE THE WATER LINE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK PLACED INSIDE OF THE CLIFF ON MAINLAND.  IT IS DISTANT 23.4 METERS FROM STATION IN AZIMUTH 136 DEG.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE, ST. THOMAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (CHN) STATION HIGH WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED BY O.W.S. IN 1918.  IT WAS RECOVERED AND USED AS A HYDRO SIGNAL IN 1967, BUT NO NOTES FROM THIS TIME ARE AVAILABLE.  THE STATION IS BEST REACHED BY SKIFF DURING CALM PERIODS.  A PROJECTING POINT TO THE EAST OF THE STATION GIVES SOME LEE EVEN WHEN SWELLS ARE RUNNING.  LANDINGS SHOULD BE MADE ON THE ROCKY BEACH JUST INSHORE OF THE PROMONTORY ON WHICH THE MARK IS LOCATED BECAUSE OF THE SUBMERGED ROCKS ON THE SEAWARD SIDE.  A LANDING CAN ALSO BE MADE INSIDE THE COVE KNOWN AS PERSERVANCE BAY.  AND THE MARK REACHED BY WALKING WESTWARD ALONG THE BEACH FOR ABOUT 600 YARDS. DUE TO SEA CONDITIONS, THE RM WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  STATION IS APPROXIMATELY MIDWAY BETWEEN BLACK POINT AND LUCAS POINT ON THE SOUTHERN COAST OF ST. THOMAS.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4.0 MILES WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE E SIDE OF THE ROAD LEADING DOWN FROM LOUISENHOE AND JUST N OF WHERE THIS ROAD DIVIDES INTO THREE ROADS, ONE RUNNING DOWN TO THE WESTWARD OF GOVERNMENT HILL, THE MIDDLE ONE OVER GOVERNMENT HILL, AND THE THIRD TOWARDS THE PARADE GROUND.  THE WITNESS MARK IS THE CONCRETE GATEWAY ABOUT 30 FEET W OF THE STATION LEADING INTO THE PREMISES OF THE HOUSE OCCUPIED BY J.C. GEORGE, THE PLUMBER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION NOT SEARCHED FOR OR USED.  NOTE--(UNDER DATE OF MAY 9, 1933) LETTER OF--DONALD S. ROREHAM, ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER OF PUBLIC WORKS, ST. THOMAS ISLAND, VIRGIN ISLANDS.  PERMISSION REQUESTED TO LOWER TRIANGULATION STATION MARK HILL 12 INCHES IN ELEVATION.  STATION IS LOCATED IN THE CITY OF ST. THOMAS, AT THE FOOT OF THE LOUISENHOE ROAD AND ABOUT 500 FEET NNE OF BLACKBEARDS CASTLE, ON GOVERNMENT HILL.  AT PRESENT THIS STATION IS SET IN A ROUGH CONCRETE MOUND IN THE ROADWAY AND PROJECTS ABOUT 10 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND, BEING SUBJECT TO DAMAGE BY VEHICULAR TRAFFIC.  EXTENSIVE REPAIR WORK IS BEING UNDERTAKEN AT THIS SECTION OF THE ROAD, AND IT IS THEREFORE NECESSARY THAT THIS PROJECTION BE DONE AWAY WITH.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON TOP OF THE OLD SUGAR FAN MILL AT ESTATE GOOD HOPE, ON THE S SHORE OF ST. CROIX, NEAR THE WESTERN END OF THE ISLAND.  THE MILL IS ABOUT 200 METERS FROM THE SHORE LINE.  STATION IS ON THE N SIDE OF THE TOP OF THE MILL, 0.35 METER FROM THE INNER EDGE OF THE WALL AND ABOUT IN LINE BETWEEN THE CENTER OF THE MILL AND WYM CHIMNEY.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED INTO DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF THE WALL OF THE MILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE N POST AT BOTTOM OF STEPS AT ENTRANCE TO THE ESTATE HOUSE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A HOLE IN AN OLD FOUNDATION ON NW SIDE OF THE MILL.  TOP OF POLE - 12.60 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION ON TOP OF THE MILL WALL, AS DESCRIBED IN 1919.  THE REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT RECOVERED AND ARE PRESUMED DESTROYED.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 2.4 MI. SOUTHEAST OF FREDERIKSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE MILL IS WITHIN A LOCKED, FENCED AREA, WITH THE NAME A. RICKEL, ON THE GATE.  THE NEXT DOOR NEIGHBOR ALLOWED ENTRY BY JUMPING THE FENCE, TO RECOVER THE STATION AS MR. RICKEL COULD NOT BE LOCATED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON THE FLAT-TOPPED GRASS WESTERN HUMMOCK OF THE RIDGE LYING BETWEEN SPRING GARDEN GUT AND HAMS BLUFF LIGHT HOUSE.  THIS IS THE SAME RIDGE THAT STATION CALEDONIA IS ON.  STATION IS IN ABOUT THE MIDDLE OF THE HILL IN AN E AND W DIRECTION, BUT IS ON THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE TOP.  MARKED BY A STANDARD STATION MARK.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN TIP OF SMALL OUTCROP IN CENTER OF TOP OF HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE OF A FLAT-TOPPED OUTCROPPING ROCK ON S SIDE OF HILL 3 FEET BELOW ITS TOP.  ROCK IS 1.2 METERS BY 0.9 METER.  TOP OF POLE - 2.70 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION DESTROYED DUE TO LEVELING OF HILLTOP.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 3.8 MI. NORTH OF FREDERIKSTED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE WESTERNMOST POINT OF INNER BRASS ISLAND, WHICH LIES OFF THE N SHORE OF ST. THOMAS ISLAND.  THE POINT IS BOLD AND ROCKY.  THE STATION IS 2 FEET BACK OF AND 4 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER LINE.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN CREVICE OF THE ROCK.  CENTER OF LIZARD ROCK IS NEARLY ON RANGE WITH HIGHEST PART OF DUTCHMANS CAP.  CRICKET ROCK LIES N 70 DEG W MAGNETIC FROM STATION AND A LARGE ROCK ON BEACH IS S 30 DEG W MAGNETIC FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1923)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON THE POINT BETWEEN ISAAC BAY AND JACK BAY, S SIDE OF THE E END OF ST. CROIX ISLAND.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE HIGH KNOLL FORMING THE E END OF THE POINT.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION MARK CEMENTED IN A CRACK BETWEEN TWO VERTICAL SLABS OF SHALE.  IT IS ABOUT 25 METERS BACK FROM THE CLIFF.  NO OBSERVATIONS WERE MADE ON THE SIGNAL AND THEREFORE THE GEOGRAPHIC POSITION OF THE STATION WAS NOT DETERMINED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  INTERSECTION STATION BY THIS PARTY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1975 STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.  SURFACE STATION MARK IS A 3-1/2 INCH IN DIAMETER BRONZE USCGS TRIANGULATION DISK STAMPED ISSAC.  THE AREA SURROUNDING THE STATION IS OVERGROWN WITH CACTUS AND THORN BUSH.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH FROM THE TURN AROUND AT THE MOST EASTERN END OF ST CROIX GO WEST ON GRAVEL ROAD FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A FORK TAKE LEFT FORK AND GO DOWN HILL SOUTHERLY FOR 50 METERS TO A FORK TAKE RIGHT FORK AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 0.3 KM (0.2 MI) TO BEACH AND ETT. PACK SOUTHWESTERLY DOWN BEACH OVER THE FIRST POINT, POINT CUDEJARRE, AND BACK DOWN TO BEACH ON WEST SIDE OF POINT CUDEJARRE, WHICH IS THE BEACH OF ISAAC BAY (NUDE BEACH), PACK WESTERLY ALONG BEACH TO NEXT POINT AND STATION ON HIGHEST POINT. NOTE, THERE IS A TRAIL UP THIS HILL THAT PASSES ABOUT 50 FEET SOUTH OF THE STATION.  THE CACTUS AND STICKER BUSHES WERE CLEARED FROM STATION SITE AT THIS TIME, BUT ARE EXPECTED TO GROW BACK RAPIDLY. ABOUT A 45 MINUTE PACK. THIS STATION CAN ALSO BE PACKED FROM THE WEST SIDE AT HUGHES POINT, BUT NO TIME WOULD BE SAVED AND THIS IS THE MORE SCENIC OF THE TWO ROUTES. A 4 WHEEL DRIVE IS REQUIRED TO GET TO THE BEACH.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. NOTE, THE STICKER BUSHES THAT GROW AROUND THE STATION WERE CLEARED IN LATE 1980, AND IN ONE YEAR GREW BACK EVEN TALLER THAN BEFORE.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE LARGEST OF THE GRASS COVERED ISLETS CALLED DURLOE CAYS LYING BETWEEN ST. JOHN ISLAND AND LOVANGO CAY.  THE STATION IS ON A LARGE BOULDER ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE ISLAND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED INTO A DEPRESSION OF A LARGE BOULDER TO THE EASTWARD.  IT BEARS S 73 DEG E AND IS DISTANT 14.27 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION AND R.M. NO. 1 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON THE POINT BETWEEN JACK BAY AND GRAPE TREE BAY, S SIDE OF ST. CROIX, NEAR ITS E END.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 5 METERS BACK OF THE CLIFF.  STATION MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER.  NO ANGLES MEASURED ON THE SIGNAL.  BANNER ON 2 BY 4 POLE ERECTED OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED. SURFACE STATION MARK IS A 3-1/2 INCH IN DIAMETER, BRONZE USCGS TRIANGULATION DISK STAMPED JACK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE YARD OF THE MOST SOUTHEASTERLY HOUSE OF GRAPETREE BAY RESORT, UNDER SOME SEA GRAPE BUSHES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1982)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED IN 1980. THE STATION IS ON PROPERTY OWNED BYDR. JEROME URBAN, ST CROIX 809 773 2152,,NEW YORK 212 744 1766. WHEN NOT IN ST CROIX SOMEONE ELSE MAY BE STAYING IN THE HOUSE.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 2008 (WEL) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN CRUZ BAY, AT THE VIRGIN ISLANDS NATIONAL PARK SERVICE VISITORS CENTER, ABOUT 45 M (147.6 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHEAST FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE VISITORS CENTER BUILDING. OWNERSHIP--NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, 1300 CRUZ BAY CREEK, ST JOHN, VI 00830, PHONE 340-776-6201.   THE STATION IS SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A SEAWALL.   IT IS LOCATED 15.2 M (49.9 FT) NORTH FROM STATION 975 1472 1, 12.4 M (40.7 FT) SOUTH FROM STATION 975 1472 2, 9.25 M (30.3 FT) WEST-SOUTHWEST FROM A FLAGPOLE, 8.75 M (28.7 FT) WEST FROM THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE BASE FOR THE VIRGIN ISLANDS NATIONAL PARK SIGN AND 8.6 M (28.2 FT) SOUTH FROM THE SOUTH EDGE OF A CONCRETE DOCK.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST KNOLL OF LITTLE ST. JAMES ISLAND.  THIS ISLAND IS OFF THE EASTERN END OF ST. THOMAS ISLAND.  THE KNOLL IS COVERED WITH SHORT GRASS.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK, CEMENTED IN THE OUTCROP ON THE TOP OF THE KNOLL.  REFERENCE MARKS NO.1 AND NO.2 ARE STANDARD BRASS DISKS CEMENTED IN THE OUTCROP.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 BEARS N 87 DEG 19 MIN W (TRUE).  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 BEARS S 10 DEG 32 MIN E (TRUE).                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1918 DESCRIPTION BY O.W.S. IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1.7 MILE S.W. OF COWPET BAY VILLAS, ST. THOMAS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION, RM 1, AND RM 2 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  THE STATION IS BEST REACHED BY BOAT (WATER TAXI IN REDHOOK BAY) TO THE ROCKY COVE ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF LITTLE ST. JAMES IS. FROM THERE IT IS A STEEP BUT SHORT PACK TO THE STATION, WITHIN SIGHT.  IF ROUGH SEA MAKES A SOUTH LANDING DANGEROUS, LAND ON THE NORTH OR WEST SIDE AND PACK UP TO STATION.  A MACHETE IS USEFUL.  ABOUT A 20 MINUTE PACK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ON LITTLE ST. JAMES IS., ABT. 2 MILES SE OF REDHOOK BAY.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS A REGULATION TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN BEDROCK LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE GRASSY CAY. DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE PROMINENT HILL E OF JUDITH FANCY ESTATE HOUSE AND NW OF GREAT PRINCESS ESTATE HOUSES.  THE HILL RISES FROM THE SHORE.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DEPRESSION OF SMALL OUTCROPPING SHALE ROCK ON THE EASTERN END OF THE HILLTOP.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION WAS MARKED BY REGULAR BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN CREVICE OF ROCK ABOUT 4 INCHES ABOVE GROUND ON THE E SHOULDER OF THE RIDGE RUNNING FROM GOAT HILL.  IT OVERLOOKS THE EXTREME EASTERLY POINT OF ST. CROIX, AND IS ABOUT 100 METERS W OF THE POINT AND 225 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  SIGNAL WAS ERECTED BUT NO ANGLES MEASURED TO IT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  STATION OCCUPIED BY THIS PARTY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US NAVY 1975 STATION WAS SEARCHED FOR, BUT NOT FOUND.  NAVOCEANO ESTABLISHED STATION BART 1975 IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA OF THE PRESUMED LOCATION OF KID.  STATION BART IS MARKED WITH A 3-1/2 INCH DIAMETER U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE BRONZE DISK TRIANGULATION MARKER STAMPED BART 1975.  TWO U.S. NAVAL OCEANOGRAPHIC OFFICE BRONZE DISK REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET FOR BART.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK WAS NOT RECOVERED AND IS BELIEVED DESTROYED DUE TO WIDENING OF THE ROAD.  A U.S. NAVY OCEANOGRAPHIC STATION, BART 1975, AND TWO REFERENCE MARKS ARE ESTABLISHED NEAR THE OLD STATION SITE INSIDE THE ROAD LOOP. BART WAS OCCUPIED AT THIS TIME.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 9.5 MILES EAST OF CHRISTIANSTED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) WHITE, BLACK AND WHITE FLAGS TACKED TO A POLE NAILED TO A MANGROVE TREE, MARK THE SIGNAL WHICH IS LOCATED ON THE OUTER POINT OF THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF THE MANGROVE ALONG THE S SHORE OF KRAUSSE LAGOON.  THE SPOT CAN BE REACHED ONLY WITH A BOAT.  A BOAT IS USUALLY KEPT NEAR THE WESTERN END OF THE LAGOON.  STATION WAS NOT PERMANENTLY MARKED. MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE.  STATION IS ABOUT 6 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER. STATION RECOVERY (1924)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  NEW SIGNAL CLOTH PLACED ON UPRIGHT AND BASE WHITEWASHED. DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS REGULAR BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN ROCK ABOUT 1 FOOT ABOVE THE GROUND ON THE TOP OF A SMALL POINT OF THE N SHORE LINE ABOVE ESTATE COTTON VALLEY (E END) AND DUE N OF GOAT HILL.  IT IS ABOUT 75 METERS BACK OF THE POINT AND 30 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.  SIGNAL ERECTED BUT NO ANGLES OBSERVED TO IT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1921)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (ERH) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED, BUT REFERENCE TO COTTON VALLEY WRONG, THE NAME SHOULD BE COTTON GARDEN. STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE TURN AROUND AT THE MOST EASTERLY TIP OF ST CROIX GO WEST, DOWNHILL ON MAIN ROAD FOR 0.9 KM (0.55 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK RIGHT AND ETT. PACK NORTHERLY OVER CREST OF HILL TO STATION ON NORTH SIDE OF HILL SLIGHTLY LOWER IN ELEVATION THAN HIGHEST PART OF HILL. CACTUS AND LOW SCRUB, STICKER BUSHES.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1993)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED. TO REACH FROM FT CHRISTIANVAERN IN CHRISTIANSTED GO EAST ON ROUTE 82 ALONG THE NORTH COAST FOR 9.5 MI (15.3 KM) TO CRAMER BEACH PARK, CONTINUE EAST FOR 0.8 MI (1.3 KM) TO A REVERSE FORK ON LEFT. TURN LEFT ON REVERSE FORK AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.1 MI (0.2 KM) TO A FORK, TAKE RIGHT FORK FOR 0.1 MILE TO END OF ROAD AND STATION.  THE STATION IS JUST TO THE NORTH OF AND BELOW THE CREST OF HILL.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE NORTHERN END OF THE RIDGE ON WHICH LIE THE RUINS OF ELIZAS RETREAT.  THIS RIDGE IS ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES E OF CHRISTIANSTED.  THE OLD STATION WAS NOT POSITIVELY RECOVERED AS THERE IS NO DESCRIPTION BUT THERE IS VERY LITTLE ROOM FOR DOUBT.  A PEDESTAL IN THE SHAPE OF THE DIAGRAM, PROJECTING 3 INCHES, AND LYING ONE FOOT N OF A WALL, 8 INCHES THICK, 3 FEET HIGH AND 7 FEET LONG WERE DISCOVERED AT THE PLACE WHERE THE CHART SHOWS THE OLD STATION TO HAVE BEEN.  THIS PEDESTAL WAS MADE OF BRICKS.  THE WALL WAS STONE.  A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK WAS CEMENTED IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF THE PEDESTAL TO MARK THE POINT LOCATED BY THE PARTY OF O. W. SWAINSON.  BOUTZBERG MILL AND W TANGENT OF BUCK ISLAND ARE ON RANGE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE PROMINENT HILL RISING FROM THE SHORE LINE MIDWAY BETWEEN LAINSTER BAY AND BROWNS BAY, AND DUE S OF LITTLE THATCH ISLAND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK ON EASTERN EDGE OF HILL.  NORTHERN TANGENT OF JEWEL CAY AND TANGENT OF MARYS POINT ARE ON RANGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A REGULATION BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A PROMINENT ROCK TO THE SOUTHWARD.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK FLUSH WITH THE GROUND AND LYING ON THE WESTERN BREAK OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 BEARS N 3 DEG 53 MIN W (TRUE) AND IS 10.22 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 BEARS S 78 DEG 34 MIN E (TRUE) AND IS 4.70 METERS DISTANT FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  HILL TOP USED FOR OFF-SHORE WORK.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE NORTHERN TIP OF LIND POINT, WESTERN END OF ST. JOHN ISLAND.  IT IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN THE ROCK. DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) MAIN SCHEME STATION LOLLIK IS ON THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE TOP TO THE HIGHEST HILL OF THE ISLAND.  MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT CEMENTED INTO ONE OF A CLUMP OF LARGE BOULDERS.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED INTO A DRILL HOLE IN A 3-FOOT BY 2 FOOT BY 2 FOOT BOULDER.  IT IS 24.4 FEET DISTANT AND IS N 87 DEG 40 MIN W (T) FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION NOT SEARCHED FOR.  USED HIGHEST POINT OF ISLAND FOR OFFSHORE HYDROGRAPHY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION LONG IS ON LONG POINT.  THIS POINT IS ABOUT 2.7 MILES E OF EAST POINT LIGHT.  STATION WAS ESTABLISHED ON THE HIGH BOLD POINT 3.5 METERS BACK FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF AND 12 METERS FROM THE E SIDE OF THE POINT.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED INTO OUTCROPPING ROCK PROJECTING 5 CENTIMETERS AND 0.4 METER IN DIAMETER.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED INTO A CREVICE 1 METER FROM EDGE OF CLIFF ON E SIDE OF POINT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION NOT SEARCHED FOR.  WHITEWASH PLACED ON ROCKS CLOSE TO SHORE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1954)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 1954 STATION WAS NOT FOUND.  A.E.S.E.P. MARK WAS FOUND AT LOCATION ANSWERING DESCRIPTION OF C AND GS LONG.  NO SIGN OF C AND GS MARK WAS FOUND.  THIS IS VERY CLOSE TO CLIFF THAT IS BEING EATEN AWAY BY SEA SO THERE IS A POSSIBILITY THAT IT MAY BE DESTROYED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON LONG POINT ON THE SOUTH WEST SHORE OF ST CROIX.  TO REACH FROM THE POST OFFICE IN FREDERICKSTED GO SOUTH FOR 1,5 KM (0.95 MI) TO A CROSS ROAD TURN LEFT AND GO EAST FOR 3.3 KM (2.05 MI) TO ASIDE ROAD RIGHT TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 2.5 KM (1,55 MI) TO A SPEED BUMP,CONTINUE FOR 0.6 KM (0.35 MI) TO A FORK (LONG POINT DRIVE) KEEP RIGHT AND GO 0.4 KM (0.25 MI) TO END OF ROAD AT HOUSE OWNED BY PHILIS VAN HORN AND STATION ON EXTREME END OF POINT.(WALK TO WEST OF HOUSE TO SHORELINE, THEN SOUTH WEST TO END OF POINT.  THE STATION IS A C AND GS BRASS DISK---UNSTAMPED---, SECURED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  IT IS LOCATED, 4.0 METERS (13.0 FT) NORTH FROM THE POINTS SOUTHERN END.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.6 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.

IT IS SAID TO BE THE SAME PIER USED BY THE LONGITUDE PARTY A NUMBER OF YEARS AGO.  AT PRESENT IT IS USED TO SUPPORT A RAIN GAUGE AND HAS A LARGE CIRCULAR CAVITY IN ITS CAP BLOCK, TO HOLD THE COPPER RECEPTACLE. THE OBJECT IS A FLAGPOLE MOUNTED IN A ON A BUILDING TOWER.  THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE CENTER OF THE FLAGPOLE.

STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS NOT SEARCHED FOR.  HILL USED FOR OFF-SHORE WORK. DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (PDC) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE CENTRAL PORTION OF ST THOMAS IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS ABOUT 0.4 MI (0.6 KM) NORTH OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE NEAR THE MAFOLIE ESTATE ON LEE HILL.  THE OBJECT IS A TRUSSWORK STEEL TOWER WITH MICROWAVE DRUMS ON ITS WEST AND SOUTH FACINGS.  THE OBJECT OBSERVED WAS AN OBSTRUCTION LIGHT ON AN EXTENSION TO ELEVATE IT ABOVE THE MICROWAVE DRUMS. DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE NORTH SHORE OF THE ISLAND OF ST. THOMAS, ON THE WESTERN POINT OF MAGENS BAY.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A HIGH ROCKY CLIFF AND ALSO THE HIGHEST OF THE TWO CLIFFS ON THIS POINT.  IT IS THE FIRST POINT THAT IS SEEN ON LEAVING MAGENS BAY.  FROM THIS CENTER, THE ENTIRE NE SHORE OF MAGENS BAY CAN BE SEEN.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A DEPRESSION OF BEDROCK.  A LARGE FLAT ROCK THAT APPEARS ON THE VERGE OF TOPPLING OVER IS VERY CLOSE BY.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 50 FEET ABOVE HIGH WATER.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (RST) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE FOR FUTURE RECOVERY.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON LONG RIDGE JUST N OF MANNING BAY ESTATE.  THE STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE RIDGE, WHICH IS ABOUT 50 METERS FROM ITS WESTERN END.  MANAGER OF BETHLEHEM NEW WORK HOUSE AND LEBANON CHIMNEY ARE ON RANGE.  BETTYS HOPE CHIMNEY BAY MILL ARE NEARLY ON RANGE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN FLAT ROCK, 1 METER IN DIAMETER, LYING FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN 1/2-METER DIAMETER ROCK OUTCROPPING FLUSH WITH THE GROUND IN CENTER OF THE RIDGE TO THE SE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 1/4 BY 1/2-METER OUTCROPPING ROCK FLUSH WITH THE GROUND, ON GENTLE SLOPE OF THE RIDGE TO THE S.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A 1/2-METER DIAMETER ROCK OUTCROPPING FLUSH WITH THE GROUND ON GENTLE SLOPE TO THE SW.  TOP OF POLE - 3.67 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (EP) THIS STATION COULD NOT BE FOUND.  A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE BUT NONE OF THE MARKS COULD BE FOUND.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--6 MILES SOUTH WEST OF CHRISTIANSTED. AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 5.9 MI. EAST OF FREDERIKSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE FLAT GRASS AND BRUSH COVERED PART OF MARIA BLUFF.  THERE ARE TWO CHIMNEY ROCKS ON THE OUTER EDGE OF THE POINT.  THE STATION IS DIRECTLY BEHIND THE WESTERN ONE AND ABOUT 75 METERS FROM IT.  STATION WAS NOT MARKED.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A REGULAR BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN THE ROCK ON THE SE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  IT BEARS S 38 DEG E AND IS DISTANT 1.6 METERS FROM THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CEG) STATION IS A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK, SET IN A 6- BY 6- BY 6-IN. CONCRETE MONUMENT ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF MARMIE HILL.  THE TOP OF THE HILL IS THICKLY WOODED WITH BRUSH UP TO 30 FT. IN HEIGHT.  MARMIE HILL IS ABOUT 5 MI. FROM CRUZ BAY ON CENTER ROAD, AND THE HILLTOP LIES ABOUT 300 FT. NW OF THE INTERSECTION OF BORDEAUX ROAD AND CENTER ROAD.  IT IS BEST TO APPROACH THE STATION FROM THE N, FROM A POINT WHERE THE CENTER ROAD CROSSES THE RIDGE ABOUT 300 FT. N OF THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE STANDARD BRASS DISKS, SET IN 6- BY 6- BY 6-IN. CONCRETE MONUMENTS.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A SPIT OF MAN MADE LAND DIRECTLY SOUTH OF THE MARTIN MARIETTA PLANT AT SOUTH CENTER PORTION OF ST CROIX.  TO REACH FROM THE ST CROIX AIRPORT GO EAST THEN NORTH ON MAIN ROAD FOR 1.6 KM (1.0 MI) TO A CROSSROAD AT STOPLIGHT,TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON NEW HIGHWAY FOR 1.6 KM (1.0 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AT MARTIN MARIETTA PLANT TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.3 KM (0.2 MI) TO GUARD HOUSE.CONTINUE FOR 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) TO A REVERSE FORK RIGHT KEEP LEFT AND GO FOR 0.6 KM (0.35 MI) TO A GUARD HOUSE (GET KEY FOR JETTY ROAD HERE) PASS GUARD HOUSE AND GO FOR 0.3 KM (0.1 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST FOR 0.3 KM (0.2 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AND SIGN (I TAKE PRIDE IN MY WORK) TURN LEFT AND GO 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO A STOP SIGN,GO FOR 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) TO A CONVEYOR (THIS AREA UNDER CONSTRUCTION) GO SOUTH WEST THROUGH CONSTRUCTION AREA FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A ROAD AT LOWER LEVEL. GET ON LOWER ROAD AND GO SOUTHERLY FOR 1.4 KM (0.9 MI) TO A GATE, CONTINUE SOUTH FOR 0.7 KM (0.45 MI) TO A FORK KEEP LEFT ON FORK (SOUTH) FOR 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO A FORK, KEEP LEFT (SOUTH) FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO STATION AT END OF ROAD.  THE STATION IS A NOS ALUMINUM DISK STAMPED---MARTIN MARIETTA 1982---, AFFIXED TOTHE TOP OF A 1.1 METER ALUMINUM ROD EMBEDED IN CONCRETE PROJECTING 3 INCHES,  IT IS LOCATED, 8.2 METERS (27.0 FT) NORTH FROM WATERS EDGE, 11.0 METERS (36.0 FT) WEST FROM WATERS EDGE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.3 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE WESTERN HILL OF MARY POINT AND IS IN THE CENTER OF THE RIDGE.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL ROCK PROJECTING 3 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1, A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN CRACK IN LEDGE ON SIDE OF OUTCROPPING ROCK ON RIDGE TO WESTWARD.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2, A REGULATION BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE FLAT-TOPPED ROCK ON N SIDE OF RIDGE.  THE ARROW POINTS ABOUT 10 DEG TO THE WESTWARD OF THE STATION.  HIGHEST PART OF JOST VAN DYKE AND LOW SADDLE ON WESTERN END OF GREAT THATCH ISLAND ARE ON RANGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1924)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) NO ATTEMPT WAS MADE AT PHYSICAL RECOVERY.  HIGHEST PART OF HILL USED AS STATION IN HYDROGRAPHY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (CEG) STATION IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A SMALL ROCK ON HIGHEST POINT OF THE W HILL OF MARY POINT.  HILLTOP IS LIGHTLY COVERED WITH BRUSH.  TO REACH STATION, PROCEED TO MARY POINT ESTATE BY BOAT OR ROAD, THENCE TO A PASTURE ON THE S SIDE OF THE RIDGE FORMING THE BACKBONE OF MARY POINT.  THIS OPEN PASTURELAND EXTENDS TO THE TOP OF RIDGE ABOUT 1/5 MI. E OF THE STATION.  THEN PROCEED W ALONG THE RIDGETOP TO THE HILLTOP AND THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK, SET IN A LEDGE ON THE SIDE OF A LARGE ROCK OUTCROP.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK, SET IN THE TOP OF A LARGE FLAT ROCK.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED ON THE SOUTHERN END OF STEVEN MAY CAY, LYING BETWEEN ST. JOHN ISLAND AND ST. THOMAS ISLAND.  STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF THE ISLAND AND IS 3 METERS FROM SOUTHERN CLIFF.  IT IS IN THE MIDDLE OF THE END OF THE ISLAND IN AN E-W DIRECTION.  A LARGE DETACHED ROCK LIES ABOUT TWENTY METERS OFF THE SOUTHERN END OF THE ISLAND.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A FLAT SMOOTH-TOPPED BOULDER ABOUT 1 FOOT BY 1 FOOT WHOSE SURFACE IS 3 CENTIMETERS ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A REGULAR BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK IN THE OUTCROPPING ROCK ON THE EXTREME W TIP OF THE S END OF THE ISLAND.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A REGULAR BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DEPRESSION IN BEDROCK ON THE SE CORNER OF THE ISLAND. TRAIL IS LABELLED AS LISA'S LOOKOUT.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE HIGHEST PART OF MT. EAGLE, THE HIGHEST HILL ON ST. CROIX.  A CIRCULAR WALL OF STONES ABOUT 10 FEET IN DIAMETER AND 4 FEET HIGH FILLED IN WITH STONES AND DIRT WAS FOUND ON TOP OF THE HILL.  IN THE CENTER WAS THE STUMP OF AN OLD FLAGPOLE.  THIS STUMP WAS REMOVED AND SUBSURFACE AND STATION MARKS, CONSISTING OF CONCRETE POSTS 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 18 INCHES LONG HAVING A STANDARD BRASS DISK IN THEIR TOPS, WERE SET IN THE HOLE.  THE STATION MARK PROJECTS SEVERAL INCHES.  REFERENCE MARKS NO.1 AND NO.2 ARE CONCRETE POSTS 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 18 INCHES LONG, HAVING STANDARD BRASS DISKS IN THEIR TOPS, SET IN THE GROUND TO THE SOUTHWARD OF THE STATION MARK.  TOP OF POLE - 4.27 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTER-AMERICAN GEODETIC SURVEY 1946 (RHL) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS IN THE CENTER OF A CIRCULAR WALL OF STONES APPROXIMATELY 4 FT. HIGH AND 10 FT. IN DIAMETER, BEING A STANDARD BRASS DISK, SET IN THE TOP OF A 6-IN. CONCRETE POST PROJECTING 4 IN. ABOVE GROUND.  ACCESS--PROCEED BY CAR TO HERMITAGE (CONSULT ST. CROIX MAP).  CONTINUE ON FOOT ALONG A WELL-DEFINED TRAIL TO THE FOOTHILLS WHERE A TRAIL BRANCHES INTO NUMEROUS DEER TRAILS AND WASH GUTS.  ANY OF THESE WILL LEAD TO A GRASSY PLATEAU IMMEDIATELY BELOW AND SE OF THE SUMMIT.  NOTE--SOME CUTTING AND CLEARING WILL BE NECESSARY IN ORDER TO SIGHT ALL STATIONS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1955)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1955 (JOP) STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND ALL MARKS WERE FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  OLD U.S.C. AND G. S. DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  DISTANCE AND DIRECTION TO REFERENCE MARKS DID NOT CHECK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  IT IS IN THE CENTER OF A CIRCULAR WALL OF STONES APPROX. 3 FT. HIGH AND 10 FT. IN DIAMETER, MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK, SET IN TOP OF A 6 IN. CONCRETE POST PROJECTING 4 IN. ABOVE THE GROUND.  ACCESS--PROCEED BY CAR ON SCENIC HIGHWAY TO SOUTH SIDE OF HILL. USE CLOSET APPROACH AND PROCEED ON FOOT USING DEER TRAILS TO TOP. HIGH GRASS IS ENCOUNTERED ON TOP OF HILL.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5 MILES NORTHEAST OF FREDERIKSTED, ST. CROIX.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE TOP OF THE KNOLL RISING TO THE SE FROM MT. PLEASANT ESTATE HOUSE.  THIS ESTATE LIES ON THE S SIDE OF CENTER LINE ROAD AND BETWEEN ESTATES BIG DIAMOND AND ADVENTURE.  STATION IS ON THE EXTREME SUMMIT OF KNOLL WHICH IS THE NORTHERN END OF RIDGE.  THE NORTHERN EDGE OF A GUT 4 METERS DEEP, IS 3 METERS S OF STATION.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK SET IN TOP OF AN 8-INCH SQUARE, 18-INCH LONG CEMENT POST, WHICH PROJECTS ABOVE THE GROUND ABOUT 4 INCHES.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK IN TOP OF A 6-INCH DIAMETER CEMENT POST.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING ROCK ON S BANK OF THE GUT.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SIMILAR DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN AN 18-INCH DIAMETER BOULDER SET FLUSH WITH THE GROUND, ABOUT 3 METERS FROM WESTERN BREAK ON TOP OF KNOLL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A SIMILAR BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN HIGHEST TIP OF LONG LOW LYING LEDGE ON THE NORTHERN SLOPE OF KNOLL.  IT IS ABOUT 10 FEET LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  TOP OF POLE - 9.62 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (VES) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (EP) THIS STATION COULD NOT BE FOUND.  A CONSIDERABLE AMOUNT OF CLEARING AND ROAD BUILDING ON TOP OF THE HILL HAS PROBABLY DESTROYED THIS MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--4 MILES EAST OF FREDERIKSTED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) STATION WAS NOT RECOVERED AFTER A THOROUGH SEARCH.  IT IS BELIEVED THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARKS WERE DESTROYED DURING ROAD BLADING.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 4.5 MI. EAST OF FREDERIKSTED.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE OLD MILL STILL EXISTS BUT HAS NO ROOF OR DEFINITE CENTER POINT.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS ON THE FIRST WELL DEFINED POINT ON THE WESTERN SIDE OF CORAL BAY, N OF RAMS HEAD.  THIS POINT IS CALLED NANNY POINT.  THE STATION IS ON THE TOP OF STEEP JAGGED CLIFF NEAR ITS NORTHEASTERN EDGE, AT THE BASE OF THE CLIFF ARE MANY DETACHED ROCKS THAT SURROUND THE POINT.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS TRIANGULATION DISK CEMENTED IN A CRACK OF THE BEDROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1924)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION FOUND AS DESCRIBED.  BASE WHITEWASHED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (KWJ) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  MARKED BY AN UNSTAMPED TRIANGULATION DISK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--5 MILES EAST OF CRUZ BAY, ST. JOHN.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS JUST E ABOUT 30 METERS FROM JOHN NEEDLES POINT.  A BROWNISH POINT MAKES CUT FROM THE E (ABOUT 10 METERS).  ROCKY LEDGE ABOUT 10 FEET FROM CLIFF SEPARATED BY GRAVEL.  A WHITE STREAK RUNNING DIAGONALLY THROUGH THE CLIFF IS DIRECTLY IN BACK OF THE STATION.  SEES MARYS POINT, GREAT THATCH CAY, LIT, THATCH, TORTOLA (W END).  ELEVATION ABOUT 3 FEET ABOVE WATER EDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION WAS FOUND AS DESCRIBED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON VAGTHUS POINT ON THE SOUTH SHORE OF ST CROIX.  TO REACH FROM THE ST CROIX AIRPORT GO EAST THEN NORTH ON MAIN ROAD FOR 1.6 KM (1.0 MI) TO A CROSSROAD AT STOPLIGHT TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON NEW HIGHWAY FOR 2.7 KM (1.7 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT. TURN RIGHT FOLLOWIHG ALONG A FENCE SOYTHERLY ON WINDING ROAD FOR 1.9 KM (1.2 MI)TO MAIN GATE OF HESS OIL GO LEFT AND EAST FOR 2.7 KM (1.65 MI) TO A T ROAD TURN RIGHT AND GO 1.9 KM (1, (1.2 MI) TO A 90 DEGREE LEFT TURN. TURN LEFT AND GO 0.1 KM (0.05 MI) TO A GRAVEL ROAD RIGHT. THE PROPERTY OWNERS LIVE DOWN THIS ROAD. CONTINUE EAST FOR 0.6 KM (0.4 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT AND GATE TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A GATE CONTINUE 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) TO A FORK. KEEP RIGHT ON FORK AND UP THE HILL FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO STATION ON THE EAST SIDE OF HIGHEST PART OF HILL.  THE STATION IS A NOS BRASS DISK STAMPED---NELTHROPP 1982--- CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT IS EXPOSED ONE FOOT ON SURFACE.  IT IS LOCATED, 6.4 METERS (21.0 FT) WEST FROM EAST SIDE OF HILL, 8.8 METERS (29.0 FT) EAST FRON THE CENTER LINE OF DIM TRACK ROAD.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SKOWN WAS 1.6 METERS. DESCRIBED BY MWJ.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) ON HIGHEST KNOLL OF RIDGE RUNNING W FROM NICHOLAS ESTATE OLD SUGAR MILL.  THE STATION IS ON THE SOUTHERN PART OF THE TOP OF THE HILL.  IT SEES BOTH NORTH SIDE AND BUTLERS BAY MILLS.  MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A 1 METER IN DIAMETER ROCK OUTCROPPING 0.4 METER.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE DISK CEMENTED IN DRILL HOLE IN THE LARGEST OF GROUP OF OUTCROPPING ROCKS ON SW EDGE OF THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 A SIMILAR DISK CEMENTED IN SHALLOW DRILL HOLE IN TOP OF ONE OF GROUP OF SMALL OUTCROPPING ROCKS ON WESTERN EDGE OF TOP OF HILL AND ABOUT 1 FOOT LOWER THAN THE STATION MARK.  TOP OF POLE - 3.38 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1977)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1977 (WFP) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT FOUND AND IS PRESUMED DESTROYED.  THE STATION MARK WAS USED AS AN AZIMUTH FOR STATION WASHINGTON.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--ABOUT 3.0 MI. NORTH OF FREDERIKSTED.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1993 THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTH CENTRAL PORTION OF ST THOMAS ISLAND IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS.  IT IS ABOUT 1 MI (1.6 KM) WEST OF CHARLOTTE AMALIE AT THE SOUTH BASE OF THE HILL AT THE NISKY MORAVIAN MISSION.  IT IS A TRUSSWORK STEEL TOWER PAINTED IN ALTERNATING SECTIONS OF RED AND WHITE WITH A RED OBSTRUCTION LIGHT AT THE TOP. THE POINT INTERSECTED WAS THE CENTER OF THE OBSTRUCTION LIGHT.                            STATION RECOVERY (2005)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 2005 (KEN) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHWEST END OF ST CROIX ON A ROCKY SHORELINE SOUTH OF HAMS BAY, 0.8 KM (0.5 MI) SOUTH OF REBECCAS PRIDE RESORT ENTRANCE AND SCENIC ROAD TURNOFF.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FREDERIKSTED MUNICIPAL PIER GO EAST FOR 1 BLOCK TO A CROSS STREET, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 5.9 KM (3.65 MI) TO THE STATION ON LEFT.  THERE ARE TWO WHITE HOUSES ON THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE ROAD, THE SOUTH HOUSE HAS AN OLD CANNON ON FRONT LAWN.  THE STATION IS ON THE ROCKY SHORELINE WITH A BEARING OF 325 DEGREES FROM THE NORTH CORNER OF LOWER STEP OF THE NORTH HOUSE.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED---NORTH SIDE 1980---, CEMENTED IN A MASS OF CONCRETE, SET FLUSH IN THE ROCK. IT IS LOCATED 2.1 METERS (6.9 FT) SOUTH FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF ROCKY SHORELINE AND 26.3 METERS (86.3 FT) NORTHWEST FROM TREELINE ALONG ROCKY SHORE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1980)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  IT HAS NO ROOF OR DEFINITE CENTER POINT.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1919 (OWS) STATION IS ON TOP OF HILL FORMING PROMINENT POINT IN THE S SHORE AT FAIRHAM ESTATE.  THE POINT FORMS THE WESTERN END OF GREAT POND BAY.  THE STATION IS 400 METERS E OF FAIRHAM OLD SUGAR FAN MILL.  MARKED BY A BRASS DISK IN A 6-INCH DIAMETER CEMENT POST 18-INCHES LONG PROJECTING ABOUT 3 INCHES ABOVE THE MIDDLE OF THE TOP OF THE HILL.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SMALL OUTCROPPING ROCK ON THE SE EDGE OF THE HILLTOP.  REFERENCE MARK NO.2 IS A SIMILAR MARK IN A ROCK OUTCROPPING ON THE MIDDLE OF THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS A SIMILAR MARK IN ROCK OUTCROPPING ON SW SIDE OF THE HILLTOP.  TOP OF POLE - 3.81 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION WAS NOT VISITED.  USED FOR OFF-SHORE WORK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1965)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1965 (VES) THE STATION AND ALL REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED EXCEPT REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 WHICH WAS ASSUMED TO BE DESTROYED.  REFERENCE MARK NO 3 WAS FOUND TO BE STAMPED NO 2.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1924 (GCM) STATION IS DESCRIBED IN BUOY LIST, 1925, U.S. LIGHTHOUSE SERVICE, PAGE 19.  MAIN CHANNEL CHRISTIANSTED HARBOR, ENTRANCE FRONT RANGE BEACON.  ON AXIS OF CHANNEL BETWEEN GREAT MIDDLE GROUND AND SCOTCH BANK.  STRUCTURE IS 14 FEET HIGH.  TWO WHITE TRIANGULAR DAYMARKS, APEX TO APEX ON PYRAMIDAL CONCRETE BASE.  STATION IS LOCATED ON POINT, A SHORT DISTANCE FROM FORT LOUISA LIGHT.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (FTS) STATION LANDING WAS MADE ON WHAT APPEARS FROM OFF SHORE TO BE A DETACHED ROCK LYING ABOUT 170 METERS FROM POINT ON W SIDE DURING A HEAVY SWELL, THIS PLACE BEING STEEP AND HAVING FOOT HOLD PLACES ON NW SIDE OF ROCK, AFFORDS EASY LANDING, WHILE IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO LAND ELSEWHERE.  THE ROCK IS SEPARATED FROM THE MAIN LAND, BUT CAN BE CROSSED BY FOOT.  THE STATION IS ON THE MIDDLE OF THREE HIGH PARTS OF THE POINT.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) MAIN SCHEME STATION OUTER BRASS IS ON THE TOP OF THE HIGHEST HILL OF OUTER BRASS ISLAND, N SIDE OF ST. THOMAS ISLAND.  MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT CEMENTED INTO A BOULDER.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 IS A STANDARD BRASS DISK CEMENTED IN THE TOP OF A BOULDER.  IT IS 2.89 METERS N 23 DEG 00 MIN E (TRUE) FROM STATION.  MARKED BY THE DANES.
DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 (GCM) STATION IS IN PLACE.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1918 (OWS) STATION IS SITUATED IN THE CENTER OF THE SMALL ISLAND LYING IN THE MIDDLE OF THE CURRENT HOLE PASSAGE BETWEEN ST. THOMAS AND ST. JOHN ISLANDS.  STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD BRASS DISK EMBEDDED IN CEMENT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1926)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1926 (GCM) STATION RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (JGC) SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.  APPROXIMATELY 1-1/2 MAN HOURS WERE SPENT LOOKING FOR THIS STATION.  THE SURFACE OF THE SMALL ROCK ISLAND IS EXTREMELY WEATHERED, AND THE MARK IS BELIEVED TO BE LOST.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE WEST END OF ST CROIX IN FREDERIKSTED, ON THE WEST END OF THE MUNICIPAL PIER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE EAST END OF FREDERICKSTED PIER GO WEST FOR 0.4 KM (0.25 MI) TO END OF MAIN PIER AND STATION.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED---PEIRCE 1980---, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE PIER, FLUSH. IT IS LOCATED 9.1 METERS (29.1 FT) SOUTH FROM THE OUTSIDE NORTH EDGE OF PIER, 8.95 METERS (29.4 FT) NORTH FROM THE OUTSIDE SOUTH EDGE OF PIER AND 0.62 METERS (2 FT) EAST FROM INSIDE WEST EDGE AT END OF PIER.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.6 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 MARK NOT FOUND.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE WEST END OF ST CROIX IN FREDERIKSTED ON THE CONCRETE BULKHEAD SOUTH OF THE MUNICIPAL PIER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE MUNICIPAL PIER GO SOUTH ON PAVED STREET FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) TO A PARKING AREA ON RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT INTO PARKING AREA AND STATION ON BULKHEAD.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD NOS DISK STAMPED---PEIRCE AZ 1 1980---, CEMENTED IN A HOLE IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE HEADWALL, FLUSH. IT IS LOCATED 24.1 METERS (79.1 FT) SOUTHWEST FROM A FIRE HYDRANT, 22.6 METERS (74.1 FT) NORTH FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF A STAIRWAY DOWN TO BEACH AND 10.95 METERS (35.9 FT) SOUTH FROM THE CENTER OF A DRAINAGE PIPE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1995 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
